 <span class="url">,                     <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.kmc.gos.pk">,                       www.kmc.gos.pk,                     </a>,                   </span>,                 </td>,               </tr>,             </tbody>,           </table>,           <p>,             <b>,               Karachi,             </b>,              (,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">,               Sindhi,             </a>,             : ,             <span lang="sd" xml:lang="sd">,               ?????,             </span>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Urdu_language" title="Urdu language" class="mw-redirect">,               Urdu,             </a>,             : ,             <span lang="ur" dir="rtl" xml:lang="ur">,               <span class="Nastaliq" title="Urdu Nastaliq" style="font-size:125%; font-family:'Jameel Noori Nastaleeq', 'Urdu Typesetting', 'Hussaini Nastaleeq', 'AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq', IranNastaliq, 'Nafees Nastaleeq', 'Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01', Nafees, 'Pak Nastaleeq', 'PDMS_Jauhar', 'Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq';">,                 ?????,               </span>,             </span>,             ? / ,             <a href="/wiki/ALA-LC" title="ALA-LC" class="mw-redirect">,               ALA-LC,             </a>,             : ,             <span title="Urdu ALA-LC transliteration" class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none">,               <i>,                 Kar?c?,               </i>,             </span>,             <small>,               IPA: ,             </small>,             <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">,               <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Hindi_and_Urdu" title="Help:IPA for Hindi and Urdu">,                 [k??r???t?i],               </a>,             </span>,             <small class="nowrap">,                (,               <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_pronunciation.ogg" title="File:Karachi pronunciation.ogg">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/13px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png" width="13" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/20px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/26px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="500"/>,               </a>,               <span class="metadata">,                 <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/37/Karachi_pronunciation.ogg" class="internal" title="Karachi pronunciation.ogg">,                   listen,                 </a>,               </span>,               ),             </small>,             ) is the largest and ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_populated_metropolitan_areas_in_Pakistan" title="List of most populated metropolitan areas in Pakistan" class="mw-redirect">,               most populous metropolitan city,             </a>,              of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,              and its main ,             <a href="/wiki/Seaport" title="Seaport" class="mw-redirect">,               seaport,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">,               financial centre,             </a>,             , as well as the ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_capitals_in_Pakistan" title="List of capitals in Pakistan">,               capital,             </a>,              of ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">,               Sindh,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Administrative_units_of_Pakistan" title="Administrative units of Pakistan">,               province,             </a>,             . The city has an estimated population of over 23.5 million people as of 2013,,             <sup id="cite_ref-http:.2F.2Ftribune.com.pk_1-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-http:.2F.2Ftribune.com.pk-1">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 1,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and an area of approximately 3,527 km,             <sup>,               2,             </sup>,              (1,362 sq mi),,             <sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-7">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 7,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-8">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 8,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              resulting in a density of more than 6,000 people per square kilometre (15,500 per square mile).,             <sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-9">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 9,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi is the ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_proper_by_population" title="List of cities proper by population">,               3rd-largest city in the world,             </a>,              by population within city limits,,             <sup id="cite_ref-citymayors1_10-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-citymayors1-10">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 10,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              the 7th largest,             <sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-11">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 11,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-12">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 12,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              urban agglomeration in the world and the ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_in_Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation_member_countries" title="List of largest cities in Organisation of Islamic Cooperation member countries">,               largest city,             </a>,              in the ,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">,               Muslim world,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-citymayors2_13-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-citymayors2-13">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 13,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              It is Pakistan's centre of banking, industry, economic activity and trade and is home to Pakistan's largest corporations, including those involved in textiles, shipping, ,             <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry" title="Automotive industry">,               automotive industry,             </a>,             , entertainment, ,             <a href="/wiki/The_arts" title="The arts">,               the arts,             </a>,             , fashion, advertising, publishing, ,             <a href="/wiki/Software_development" title="Software development">,               software development,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Medical_research" title="Medical research">,               medical research,             </a>,             . The city is a hub of higher education in ,             <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">,               South Asia,             </a>,              and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">,               Muslim world,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-14">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 14,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi is ranked as a ,             <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">,               beta world city,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-15">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 15,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-16">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 16,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              It was the capital of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,              until ,             <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">,               Islamabad,             </a>,              was constructed as a capital to spread development evenly across the country and to prevent it from being concentrated in Karachi.,             <sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-17">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 17,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi is the location of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">,               Port of Karachi,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_Qasim" title="Port Qasim">,               Port Bin Qasim,             </a>,             , two of the region's largest and busiest ports. After the independence of Pakistan, the city population increased dramatically when hundreds of thousands of ,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">,               Muslim,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Muhajir_people" title="Muhajir people">,               Muhajirs,             </a>,              from ,             <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">,               India,             </a>,              fleeing from ,             <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims" title="Persecution of Muslims">,               anti-Muslim,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Pogram" title="Pogram" class="mw-redirect">,               pograms,             </a>,              and from other parts of South Asia came to settle in Karachi.,             <sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-18">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 18,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             The city is located on the ,             <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">,               Arabian Sea,             </a>,              coastline. It is known as the Uroos ul Bilaad "City of Lights",             <sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-19">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 19,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-20">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 20,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and "The Bride of the Cities" for its liveliness,,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">,               [,               <i>,                 <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">,                   <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2014)">,                     citation needed,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </i>,               ],             </sup>,              and the "City of the Quaid", having been the birth and burial place of ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Quaid-e-Azam" title="Quaid-e-Azam" class="mw-redirect">,                 Quaid-e-Azam,               </a>,             </i>,             , the Great Leader, ,             <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">,               Muhammad Ali Jinnah,             </a>,             , the founder of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,             , who made the city his home after Pakistan's ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">,               independence,             </a>,              from the ,             <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">,               British Raj,             </a>,              on 14 August 1947.,           </p>,           <p>,           </p>,           <div id="toc" class="toc">,             <div id="toctitle">,           </li>,               <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-27">,                 <a href="#See_also">,                   <span class="tocnumber">,                     14,              References,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </li>,               <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-29">,                 <a href="#External_links">,                   <span class="tocnumber">,                     16,                   </span>,                   <span class="toctext">,                     External links,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </li>,             </ul>,           </div>,           <p>,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="History">,               History,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/History_of_Karachi" title="History of Karachi">,               History of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">,             See also: ,             <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Karachi_history" title="Timeline of Karachi history" class="mw-redirect">,               Timeline of Karachi history,             </a>,           </div>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">,               Early history,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             Karachi was known to the ancient ,             <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">,               Greeks,             </a>,              by many names: ,             <a href="/wiki/Krokola" title="Krokola">,               Krokola,             </a>,             , the place where ,             <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">,               Alexander the Great,             </a>,              camped to prepare a fleet for ,             <a href="/wiki/Babylonia" title="Babylonia">,               Babylonia,             </a>,              after his campaign in the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">,               Indus Valley,             </a>,             ; ,             <a href="/wiki/Morontobara" title="Morontobara" class="mw-redirect">,               Morontobara,             </a>,              (probably ,             <a href="/wiki/Manora,_Karachi" title="Manora, Karachi">,               Manora,             </a>,              island near ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">,               Karachi harbour,             </a>,             ), from whence Alexander's admiral ,             <a href="/wiki/Nearchus" title="Nearchus">,               Nearchus,             </a>,              set sail; and ,             <a href="/wiki/Barbarikon" title="Barbarikon">,               Barbarikon,             </a>,             , a port of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Bactria" title="Bactria">,               Bactrian,             </a>,              kingdom. It was later known to the ,             <a href="/wiki/Arab_people" title="Arab people" class="mw-redirect">,               Arabs,             </a>,              as ,             <a href="/wiki/Debal" title="Debal">,               Debal,             </a>,              from where ,             <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Qasim" title="Muhammad bin Qasim">,               Muhammad bin Qasim,             </a>,              led his conquering force into South Asia in AD 712.,             <sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-21">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 21,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi was reputedly founded as "Kolachi" by ,             <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">,               Baloch,             </a>,              tribes from ,             <a href="/wiki/Balochistan_(region)" title="Balochistan (region)" class="mw-redirect">,               Balochistan,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Makran" title="Makran">,               Makran,             </a>,             , who established a small fishing community in the area.,             <sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-22">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 22,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Descendants of the original community still live in the area on the small island of Abdullah Goth, which is located near the Karachi Port. The original name "Kolachi" survives in the name of a well-known Karachi locality named ,             <a href="/wiki/Mai_Kolachi" title="Mai Kolachi">,               Mai Kolachi,             </a>,              in ,             <a href="/wiki/Balochi_language" title="Balochi language">,               Balochi,             </a>,             . ,             <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ghazi_Beg" title="Mirza Ghazi Beg">,               Mirza Ghazi Beg,             </a>,             , the ,             <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">,               Mughal,             </a>,              administrator of ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">,               Sindh,             </a>,             , is among the first historical figures credited for the development of coastal Sindh (consisting of regions such as the Makran coast and the Mehran delta),,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">,               [,               <i>,                 <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countering_systemic_bias" title="Wikipedia:WikiProject Countering systemic bias">,                   <span title="The geographic scope near this tag is ambiguous. (February 2014)">,                     where?,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </i>,               ],             </sup>,              including the cities of ,             <a href="/wiki/Thatta" title="Thatta">,               Thatta,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Bhambore" title="Bhambore" class="mw-redirect">,               Bhambore,             </a>,              and Karachi.,           </p>,           <p>,             The village that later grew out of this settlement was known as ,             <a href="/wiki/Kolachi-jo-Goth" title="Kolachi-jo-Goth" class="mw-redirect">,               Kolachi-jo-Goth,             </a>,              (Village of Kolachi in ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">,               Sindhi,             </a>,             ). By the late 1720s, the village was trading across the ,             <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">,               Arabian Sea,             </a>,              with ,             <a href="/wiki/Muscat,_Oman" title="Muscat, Oman">,               Muscat,             </a>,              and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">,               Persian Gulf,             </a>,              region. The local ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_people" title="Sindhi people">,               Sindhi,             </a>,              populace built a small fort, that was constructed for the protection of the city, armed with cannons imported by Sindhi sailors from Muscat, ,             <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">,               Oman,             </a>,             . The fort had two main gateways: one facing the sea, known as Kharra Darwaaza (Brackish Gate) (,             <a href="/wiki/Kharadar" title="Kharadar" class="mw-redirect">,               Kharadar,             </a>,             ) and the other facing the ,             <a href="/wiki/Lyari_River" title="Lyari River">,               Lyari River,             </a>,              known as the Meet'ha Darwaaza (Sweet Gate) (,             <a href="/wiki/Mithadar" title="Mithadar">,               Mithadar,             </a>,             ), which correspond to the modern areas of ,             <a href="/wiki/Kharadar" title="Kharadar" class="mw-redirect">,               Kharadar,             </a>,              and Mithadar.,           </p>,           <p>,             The name Karachi was used for the first time in a ,             <a href="/wiki/Dutch_language" title="Dutch language">,               Dutch,             </a>,              document of 1742, when a merchant ship ,             <i>,               de Ridderkerk,             </i>,              shipwrecked nearby its coast.,             <sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-23">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 23,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-24">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 24,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="British_rule">,               British rule,             </span>,           </h3>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg/220px-429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg/330px-429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg/440px-429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg 2x" data-file-width="741" data-file-height="464"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:429068485_5f192dcf9f_o.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <a href="/wiki/D._J._Science_College" title="D. J. Science College">,                   Dayaram Jethmal College,                 </a>,                  in the 19th century,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg/220px-Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg/330px-Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg/440px-Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="800"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_Airport_in_1943_during_World_War_II.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_International_Airport" title="Jinnah International Airport">,                   Karachi Airport,                 </a>,                  in 1943 during the ,                 <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">,                   World War II,                 </a>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             After some exploratory missions to the area, the ,             <a href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" title="British East India Company" class="mw-redirect">,               British East India Company,             </a>,              captured the town when ,             <a href="/wiki/HMS_Wellesley" title="HMS Wellesley">,               HMS ,               <i>,                 Wellesley,               </i>,             </a>,              anchored off Manora island on 1 February 1839. Two days later, the little fort surrendered.,             <sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-25">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 25,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The town was later annexed to ,             <a href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India" class="mw-redirect">,               British India,             </a>,              when ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">,               Sindh,             </a>,              was annexed by Major General ,             <a href="/wiki/Charles_James_Napier" title="Charles James Napier">,               Charles James Napier,             </a>,              at the ,             <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Miani" title="Battle of Miani">,               Battle of Miani,             </a>,              on 17 February 1843.,           </p>,           <p>,             On his departure in 1847, ,             <a href="/wiki/Charles_James_Napier" title="Charles James Napier">,               Napier,             </a>,              is said to have remarked, "Would that I could come again to see you in your grandeur!" Karachi was made the capital of Sindh in the 1840s. On Napier's departure, it was added along with the rest of Sindh to the ,             <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Presidency" title="Bombay Presidency">,               Bombay Presidency,             </a>,             , a move that caused resentment among the native ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_people" title="Sindhi people">,               Sindhis,             </a>,             . The British realised the importance of the city as a military cantonment and as a port for exporting the produce of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">,               Indus River,             </a>,              basin, and developed its ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">,               harbour,             </a>,              for shipping. The foundations of a city municipal government were laid down and infrastructure development was undertaken. New businesses opened up and the population of the town began rising.,           </p>,           <p>,             The arrival of the troops of the ,             <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">,               Company Bahadur,             </a>,              in 1839 spawned the foundation of the new section, the military cantonment. The cantonment formed the basis of the 'white' town, where the native population had restricted access. The 'white' town was modelled after English industrial parent-cities, where work and residential spaces were separated, as were residential from recreational places. The 'native' town in the northwest, was enlarged to accommodate the burgeoning mercantile population. When the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">,               Indian Rebellion of 1857,             </a>,              broke out in ,             <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">,               South Asia,             </a>,             , the 21st Native Infantry, then stationed in Karachi, declared allegiance to rebels and joining their numbers on 10 September 1857. Nevertheless, the British were able to quickly reassert control over Karachi and defeat the uprising. Officer William 'Waf' Frost was considered to be instrumental in quelling the rebellion and was rewarded for his valor with an ,             <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire" title="Order of the British Empire">,               Order of the British Empire,             </a>,             . This was awarded to him on 23 April 1858. However, he remains unpopular in areas of Karachi to this day.,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi04.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a9/Karachi04.jpg/250px-Karachi04.jpg" width="250" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a9/Karachi04.jpg/375px-Karachi04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a9/Karachi04.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="339"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi04.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <a href="/wiki/Elphinstone_Street" title="Elphinstone Street" class="mw-redirect">,                   Elphinstone Street,                 </a>,                  in 1930,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             In 1864, the first telegraphic message was sent from ,             <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">,               South Asia,             </a>,              to ,             <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">,               England,             </a>,             , when a direct ,             <a href="/wiki/Telegraph" title="Telegraph" class="mw-redirect">,               telegraph,             </a>,              connection was laid between Karachi and ,             <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">,               London,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-26">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 26,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1878, the city was connected to the rest of British India by rail. Public building projects, such as ,             <a href="/wiki/Frere_Hall" title="Frere Hall">,               Frere Hall,             </a>,              (1865) and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Empress_Market" title="Empress Market">,               Empress Market,             </a>,              (1890), were undertaken. In 1876, ,             <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">,               Muhammad Ali Jinnah,             </a>,             , the founder of Pakistan, was born in the city according to some accounts, which by now had become a bustling city with mosques, temples, courthouses, paved streets and a harbour. By 1899, Karachi had become the largest wheat exporting port in the East.,             <sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-27">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 27,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Before 1880 the majority of the population of Karachi consisted of the indigenous ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_people" title="Sindhi people">,               Sindhis,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">,               Balochis,             </a>,              (who also spoke Sindhi as a second language).,           </p>,           <p>,             These developments in Karachi resulted in an influx of economic migrants: ,             <a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">,               Parsis,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">,               Hindus,             </a>,             , Christians, ,             <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">,               Jews,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Marathis" title="Marathis" class="mw-redirect">,               Marathis,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Goan_Christian" title="Goan Christian" class="mw-redirect">,               Goan Christian,             </a>,             , Chinese, British, ,             <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">,               Arabs,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_people" title="Gujarati people">,               Gujaratis,             </a>,             . The population of the city was about 105,000 inhabitants by the end of the 19th century, with a mix of nationalities. British colonialists embarked on works of sanitation and transportation – such as gravel paved streets, drains, street sweepers, and a network of ,             <a href="/wiki/Tram" title="Tram">,               Trams,             </a>,              and horse-drawn trolleys.,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Independent_Pakistan">,               Independent Pakistan,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             By the time of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,             's ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">,               independence,             </a>,              in 1947, Karachi had become a bustling metropolis with slightly under half a million people, and classical and colonial European styled buildings lining the city's thoroughfares. Karachi was chosen as the capital of Pakistan, which at the time included present-day ,             <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">,               Bangladesh,             </a>,             , approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) to the east, and not physically connected to Pakistan. In 1947, Karachi was the focus for settlement by ,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">,               Muslim,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Muhajir_people" title="Muhajir people">,               Muhajirs,             </a>,              fleeing from ,             <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims" title="Persecution of Muslims">,               anti-Muslim,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Pogram" title="Pogram" class="mw-redirect">,               pograms,             </a>,              in India, who expanded the city's population and transformed its demographics and economy. In 1958, the capital of Pakistan was moved from Karachi to ,             <a href="/wiki/Rawalpindi" title="Rawalpindi">,               Rawalpindi,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <p>,             During the 1960s, Karachi was seen as an economic role model around the world. Many countries sought to emulate Pakistan's economic planning strategy and one of them, ,             <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">,               South Korea,             </a>,             , copied the city's second "Five-Year Plan" and the World Financial Center in ,             <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">,               Seoul,             </a>,              is designed and modeled after Karachi.,             <sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-28">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 28,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-29">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 29,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi had both a municipal corporation and a Karachi Divisional Council in the 1960s, which developed schools, colleges, roads, municipal gardens, and parks. The Karachi Divisional Council had working committees for education, roads, and residential societies development and planning.,             <sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-30">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 30,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In the late 1960s, the capital shifted from ,             <a href="/wiki/Rawalpindi" title="Rawalpindi">,               Rawalpindi,             </a>,              to the newly built ,             <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">,               Islamabad,             </a>,             . This marked the start of a long period of decline in the city, marked by a lack of development.,           </p>,           <p>,             On 4 December 1971, the Indian Navy launched ,             <a href="/wiki/Operation_Trident_(1971)" title="Operation Trident (1971)">,               Operation Trident,             </a>,              and its follow-up ,             <a href="/wiki/Operation_Python" title="Operation Python">,               Operation Python,             </a>,              on Karachi harbour during the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1971">,               Indo-Pakistani War of 1971,             </a>,              that resulted in the first use of anti-ship missiles in the region, as well as the first sinking of naval vessels during hostilities in the region since World War II. During the operation it also targeted Kemari oil storage tanks on the south of the harbour, which were burnt and destroyed, causing heavy losses to the country. The 1970s also saw major labour struggles in Karachi's industrial estates (see ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_labour_unrest_of_1972" title="Karachi labour unrest of 1972">,               Karachi labour unrest of 1972,             </a>,             ). The 1980s and 1990s saw an influx of refugees from the ,             <a href="/wiki/Soviet_war_in_Afghanistan" title="Soviet war in Afghanistan">,               Soviet war in Afghanistan,             </a>,              into Karachi; they were followed in smaller numbers by refugees escaping from ,             <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">,               Iran,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-31">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 31,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              After the 1970s Karachi has become home to about five to seven million Pashtuns, which is more than Peshawar, Kabul or Kandahar.,             <sup id="cite_ref-pbs_32-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pbs-32">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 32,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-The_National_33-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-The_National-33">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 33,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In the late 1980s and early 1990s, ethnic and political violence broke out across the city between Muhajir followers of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Mohajir_Qaumi_Movement" title="Mohajir Qaumi Movement" class="mw-redirect">,               Mohajir Qaumi Movement,             </a>,              fought with ethnic Sindhis, Pashtuns, Punjabis, and security forces. As a result, the ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Army" title="Pakistan Army">,               Army,             </a>,              was deployed to restore peace in the city.,             <sup id="cite_ref-Minahan_34-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Minahan-34">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 34,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Today, Karachi is an important financial and industrial centre and handles most of the overseas trade of Pakistan and the world, mainly the Asian countries. It accounts for a significant share of the GDP of Pakistan.,             <sup id="cite_ref-adb_35-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-adb-35">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 35,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">,               Geography,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Karachi" title="Geography of Karachi">,               Geography of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:122px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg/120px-Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg" width="120" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg/180px-Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg/240px-Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4537" data-file-height="5000"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_ali_2010008_lrg.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Satellite view of Karachi,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi is located in the south of Pakistan, on the coast of the Arabian Sea. Its geographic coordinates are 24°51? N 67°02? E. Most of the land consisted largely of flat or rolling plains, with hills on the western and ,             <a href="/wiki/Manora,_Karachi" title="Manora, Karachi">,               Manora,             </a>,              Island and the Oyster Rocks. The Arabian Sea beach lines the southern coastline of Karachi. ,             <a href="/wiki/Mangrove" title="Mangrove">,               Mangroves,             </a>,              and creeks of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indus_River_Delta" title="Indus River Delta">,               Indus delta,             </a>,              can be found toward the southeast side of the city. Toward the west and the north is ,             <a href="/wiki/Cape_Monze" title="Cape Monze">,               Cape Monze,             </a>,             , locally known as ,             <a href="/wiki/Ras_Muari" title="Ras Muari" class="mw-redirect">,               Ras Muari,             </a>,             , an area marked by projecting sea cliffs and rocky sandstone promontories. Some excellent beaches can be found in this area. ,             <a href="/wiki/Khasa_Hills" title="Khasa Hills" class="mw-redirect">,               Khasa Hills,             </a>,              lie in the northwest and form the border between ,             <a href="/wiki/North_Nazimabad_Town" title="North Nazimabad Town">,               North Nazimabad Town,             </a>,             <sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-36">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 36,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Orangi_Town" title="Orangi Town">,               Orangi Town,             </a>,             . The ,             <a href="/wiki/Manghopir_Hills" title="Manghopir Hills">,               Manghopir Hills,             </a>,              lies northwest of Karachi, between ,             <a href="/wiki/Hub_River" title="Hub River">,               Hub River,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Manghopir" title="Manghopir">,               Manghopir,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <p>,             The rivers in Karachi are ,             <a href="/wiki/Malir_River" title="Malir River">,               Malir River,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Lyari_River" title="Lyari River">,               Lyari River,             </a>,             . The ,             <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">,               Indus River,             </a>,              flood plain is near Karachi.,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">,               Climate,             </span>,           </h3>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Karachi" title="Climate of Karachi">,               Climate of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:July_floods_karachi_(2).jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/July_floods_karachi_%282%29.jpg/175px-July_floods_karachi_%282%29.jpg" width="175" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/July_floods_karachi_%282%29.jpg/263px-July_floods_karachi_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/July_floods_karachi_%282%29.jpg/350px-July_floods_karachi_%282%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:July_floods_karachi_(2).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Sunset in Karachi,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Located on the coast, Karachi has an ,             <a href="/wiki/Arid_climate" title="Arid climate" class="mw-redirect">,               arid climate,             </a>,              with low average precipitation levels (approx. 250 mm (9.8 in) per annum), the bulk of which occurs during the July–August ,             <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">,               monsoon,             </a>,              season. Winters are mild and dry, while the summers are warm and humid; the proximity to the sea maintains humidity levels at a near-constant high and cool sea breezes relieve the heat of the summer months. December and January are dry and pleasant as compared to the warm summers that dominate through the late spring (March) to the pre-monsoon season (June). Compared to other parts of Pakistan, Karachi's weather is considered mild and can be compared to Florida's weather (except for the precipitation).,           </p>,           <p>,             The city's highest monthly rainfall, 429.3 mm (16.90 in), occurred in July 1967.,             <sup id="cite_ref-pakmet_37-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pakmet-37">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 37,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The city's highest rainfall in 24 hours occurred on 7 August 1953, when about 278.1 millimetres (10.95 in) of rain lashed the city, resulting in major flooding.,             <sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-38">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 38,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi's highest recorded temperature is 47 °C (117 °F), which was recorded on 18 June 1979,,             <sup id="cite_ref-pakmet_37-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pakmet-37">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 37,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and the lowest is 0.0 °C (32.0 °F), recorded on 21 January 1934.,             <sup id="cite_ref-pakmet_37-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pakmet-37">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 37,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             <br/>,           </p>,           <table class="wikitable collapsible" style="width:90%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height: 1.1em; margin:auto;">,             <tbody>,               <tr>,                 <th colspan="14">,       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">,               Economy,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Karachi" title="Economy of Karachi">,               Economy of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright" style="width: 212px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Project_of_Bahria_Icon_Tower_2014-01-20_14-35.jpeg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" title="Bahria Icon Tower">,                     Bahria Icon Tower,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachiskyline.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt=""       <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Habib_Bank_Plaza.jpeg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Habib_Bank_Plaza.jpeg/200px-Habib_Bank_Plaza.jpeg" width="200" height="301" data-file-height="432"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Habib_Bank_Plaza" title="Habib Bank Plaza">,                     Habib Bank Plaza,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:MCB2.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/MCB2.jpg/200px-MCB2.jpg" width="200" height="267" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/MCB2.jpg/300px-MCB2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/MCB2.jpg/400px-MCB2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="1024"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/MCB_Tower" title="MCB Tower">,                     MCB Tower,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:My_collage.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="My collage.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/My_collage.jpg/220px-My_collage.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/My_collage.jpg/330px-My_collage.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/My_collage.jpg/440px-My_collage.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5120" data-file-height="3840"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:My_collage.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi is the financial and commercial capital of Pakistan.,             <sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-41">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 41,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In line with its status as a major port and the country's largest metropolis, it accounts for a lion's share of Pakistan's revenue. According to the ,             <a href="/wiki/Federal_Board_of_Revenue" title="Federal Board of Revenue" class="mw-redirect">,               Federal Board of Revenue,             </a>,             's 2006–2007 year book, tax and customs units in Karachi were responsible for 46.75% of direct taxes, 33.65% of federal excise tax, and 23.38% of domestic sales tax.,             <sup id="cite_ref-fbr0607_42-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-fbr0607-42">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 42,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi accounts for 75.14% of customs duty and 79% of sales tax on imports.,             <sup id="cite_ref-fbr0607_42-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-fbr0607-42">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 42,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Therefore, Karachi collects 53.38% of the total collections of the Federal Board of Revenue, out of which 53.33% are customs duty and sales tax on imports.,             <sup id="cite_ref-fbr0607_42-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-fbr0607-42">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 42,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              (Note: Revenue collected from Karachi includes revenue from some other areas since the Large Tax Unit (LTU) Karachi and Regional Tax Offices (RTOs) Karachi, Hyderabad, Sukkur &amp; Quetta cover the entire province of Sindh and Balochistan).,             <sup id="cite_ref-fbr0607_42-3" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-fbr0607-42">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 42,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi's indigenous contribution to national revenue is around 25%.,             <sup id="cite_ref-adb_35-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-adb-35">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 35,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tleft">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Composition_of_Karachi%27s_Economy.png" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/45/Composition_of_Karachi%27s_Economy.png/220px-Composition_of_Karachi%27s_Economy.png" width="220" height="247" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/4/45/Composition_of_Karachi%27s_Economy.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/4/45/Composition_of_Karachi%27s_Economy.png 2x" data-file-width="327" data-file-height="367"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Composition_of_Karachi%27s_Economy.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Composition of Karachi's economy,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi's contribution to Pakistan's manufacturing sector amounts to approximately 30 percent.,             <sup id="cite_ref-stepmother_43-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-stepmother-43">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 43,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              A substantial part of Sindh's gross domestic product (GDP) is attributed to Karachi,             <sup id="cite_ref-gdp4_44-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-gdp4-44">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 44,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-dawngdp2_45-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-dawngdp2-45">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 45,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              (the GDP of Sindh as a percentage of Pakistan's total GDP has traditionally hovered around 28%–30%; for more information, see ,             <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Sindh" title="Economy of Sindh">,               economy of Sindh,             </a>,             ).,             <sup id="cite_ref-gdp4_44-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-gdp4-44">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 44,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-dawngdp2_45-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-dawngdp2-45">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 45,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-dawngdp1_46-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-dawngdp1-46">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 46,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-dawngdp3_47-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-dawngdp3-47">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 47,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi's GDP is around 20% of the total GDP of Pakistan.,             <sup id="cite_ref-adb_35-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-adb-35">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 35,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-coastline_48-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-coastline-48">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 48,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              A ,             <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">,               PricewaterhouseCoopers,             </a>,              study released in 2009, which surveyed the ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">,               2008 GDP of the top cities,             </a>,              in the world, calculated Karachi's GDP (PPP) to be $78 billion,             <sup id="cite_ref-pwc1_49-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pwc1-49">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 49,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              (projected to be $193 billion in 2025 at a growth rate of 5.5%).,             <sup id="cite_ref-pwc1_49-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pwc1-49">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 49,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              It confirmed Karachi's status as Pakistan's largest economy, well ahead of the next two biggest cities ,             <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">,               Lahore,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Faisalabad" title="Faisalabad">,               Faisalabad,             </a>,             , which had a reported GDP (PPP) in 2008 of $40 billion and $14 billion, respectively.,             <sup id="cite_ref-pwc1_49-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pwc1-49">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 49,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi's high GDP is based on its industrial base, with a high dependency on the financial sector. Textiles, cement, steel, heavy machinery, chemicals, food, banking and insurance are the major segments contributing to Karachi's GDP. In February 2007, the ,             <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">,               World Bank,             </a>,              identified Karachi as the most business-friendly city in Pakistan.,             <sup id="cite_ref-dawn4_50-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-dawn4-50">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 50,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi is the nerve center of Pakistan's economy. The economic stagnation caused by political anarchy, ethnic strife and resultant military operation during the late 1980s and 1990s led to an exit of industry from Karachi. Most of Pakistan's public and private banks are headquartered on Karachi's ,             <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Ismail_Chundrigar_Road" title="Ibrahim Ismail Chundrigar Road">,               I. I. Chundrigar Road,             </a>,             ; according to a 2001 report, nearly 60% of the cashflow of the Pakistani economy takes place on I. I. Chundrigar Road. Most major foreign ,             <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">,               multinational corporations,             </a>,              operating in Pakistan have their headquarters in Karachi. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Stock_Exchange" title="Karachi Stock Exchange">,               Karachi Stock Exchange,             </a>,              is the largest stock exchange in Pakistan, and is considered by many economists to be one of the prime reasons for Pakistan's 8% GDP growth across 2005.,             <sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-51">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 51,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              A recent report by ,             <a href="/wiki/Credit_Suisse" title="Credit Suisse">,               Credit Suisse,             </a>,              on Pakistan's stock market is a testimonial to its strong fundamentals, estimating Pakistan's relative return on equities at 26.7 percent, compared to Asia's 11 percent.,             <sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-52">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 52,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi has seen an expansion of ,             <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">,               information and communications technology,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Electronic_media" title="Electronic media">,               electronic media,             </a>,              and has become the software outsourcing hub of Pakistan. ,             <a href="/wiki/Call_centre" title="Call centre">,               Call centres,             </a>,              for foreign companies have been targeted as a significant area of growth, with the government making efforts to reduce taxes by as much as 10% to gain foreign investments in the IT sector.,             <sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-53">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 53,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-54">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 54,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Many of Pakistan's independent ,             <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Pakistan" title="Television in Pakistan">,               television,             </a>,              and radio stations are based in Karachi, including world-popular ,             <a href="/wiki/Business_Plus_(TV_Channel)" title="Business Plus (TV Channel)">,               Business Plus,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/AAJ_TV" title="AAJ TV">,               AAJ News,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Geo_TV" title="Geo TV">,               Geo TV,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Kawish_Television_Network" title="Kawish Television Network">,               KTN,             </a>,             ,,             <sup id="cite_ref-ktn_55-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-ktn-55">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 55,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <a href="/wiki/Sindh_TV" title="Sindh TV">,               Sindh TV,             </a>,             ,,             <sup id="cite_ref-sindhtv_56-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-sindhtv-56">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 56,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <a href="/wiki/CNBC_Pakistan" title="CNBC Pakistan" class="mw-redirect">,               CNBC Pakistan,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/TV_ONE_(Pakistan)" title="TV ONE (Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect">,               TV ONE,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/ARY_Digital" title="ARY Digital">,               ARY Digital,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Indus_Media_Group" title="Indus Media Group">,               Indus Television Network,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Samaa_TV" title="Samaa TV" class="mw-redirect">,               Samaa TV,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Dawn_News" title="Dawn News">,               Dawn News,             </a>,             , as well as several local stations.,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi has large industrial zones such as Karachi Export Processing Zone, SITE, ,             <a href="/wiki/Korangi" title="Korangi">,               Korangi,             </a>,             , Northern Bypass Industrial Zone, Bin Qasim and North Karachi, located on the fringes of the main city.,             <sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-57">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 57,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Its primary areas of industry are textiles, pharmaceuticals, steel, and automobiles. In addition, Karachi has a cottage industry and there is a Free Zone with an annual growth rate of nearly 6.5%. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Expo_Centre" title="Karachi Expo Centre" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Expo Centre,             </a>,              hosts regional and international exhibitions.,             <sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-58">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 58,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template">,               <span style="white-space: nowrap;">,                 [,                 <i>,                   <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot">,                     <span title=" since February 2014">,                       dead link,                     </span>,                   </a>,                 </i>,                 ],               </span>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <table class="wikitable">,             <tbody>,               <tr>,                 <th>,                   Name of Estate,                 </th>,                 <th>,
