      <span>,                         [,                       </span>,                       69,                       <span>,                         ],                       </span>,                     </a>,                   </sup>,                 </td>,               </tr>,             </tbody>,           </table>,           <p>,             There are development projects proposed, approved and under construction in Karachi. Among projects of note, ,             <a href="/wiki/Emaar_Properties" title="Emaar Properties">,               Emaar Properties,             </a>,              is proposing to invest $43bn (£22.8bn) in Karachi to develop ,             <a href="/wiki/Bundal_Island" title="Bundal Island">,               Bundal Island,             </a>,             , which is a 12,000 acres (49 km,             <sup>,               2,             </sup>,             ) island just off the coast of Karachi.,             <sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-70">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 70,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Port_Trust" title="Karachi Port Trust">,               Karachi Port Trust,             </a>,              is planning a Rs. 20 billion, 1,947 feet (593 m) high ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_Tower_Complex" title="Port Tower Complex">,               Port Tower Complex,             </a>,              on the ,             <a href="/wiki/Clifton,_Karachi" title="Clifton, Karachi">,               Clifton,             </a>,              shoreline.,             <sup id="cite_ref-tower_71-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-tower-71">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 71,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-dawn_72-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-dawn-72">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 72,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              It will comprise a hotel, a shopping center, an exhibition center and a ,             <a href="/wiki/Revolving_restaurant" title="Revolving restaurant">,               revolving restaurant,             </a>,              with a viewing gallery offering a panoramic view of the coastline and the city.,             <sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-73">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 73,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             As one of the most rapidly growing cities in the world, Karachi faces challenges that are central to many developing metropolises, including traffic congestion, pollution, poverty and street crime. These problems continue to earn Karachi low rankings in livability comparisons: ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">,                 The Economist,               </a>,             </i>,              ranked Karachi fourth least liveable city amongst the 132 cities surveyed,             <sup id="cite_ref-Economist_Survey_74-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Economist_Survey-74">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 74,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/BusinessWeek" title="BusinessWeek" class="mw-redirect">,                 BusinessWeek,               </a>,             </i>,              ranked it 175 out of 215 in livability in 2007, down from 170 in 2006.,             <sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-75">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 75,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              An average of six people per day are killed in Karachi and Former Police Chief Ahmed Farooqi has said that the violence is beyond the control of law enforcement.,             <sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-76">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 76,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              By 2013 the murder rate had doubled to about a dozen per day.,             <sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-77">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 77,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:99%; max-width:1108px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">,                 <a href="/wiki/File:Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg" class="image" title="Skyline of Karachi as seen from the I.I. Chundrigar Road.">,                   <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dc/Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg/1100px-Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg" width="1100" height="256" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dc/Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg/1650px-Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dc/Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg/2200px-Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="1207"/>,                 </a>,               </div>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Skyline_of_Karachi.jpg" title="Enlarge">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6b/Magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" data-file-width="15" data-file-height="11"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Skyline of Karachi as seen from the ,                 <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Ismail_Chundrigar_Road" title="Ibrahim Ismail Chundrigar Road">,                   I.I. Chundrigar Road,                 </a>,                 .,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Civic_administration">,               Civic administration,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main articles: ,             <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Karachi" title="Politics of Karachi">,               Politics of Karachi,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Karachi" title="List of mayors of Karachi">,               List of mayors of Karachi,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_Union_Councils_of_Karachi" title="List of Union Councils of Karachi">,               List of Union Councils of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:205px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:KMCbuilding.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/KMCbuilding.jpg/203px-KMCbuilding.jpg" width="203" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/KMCbuilding.jpg/305px-KMCbuilding.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/KMCbuilding.jpg/406px-KMCbuilding.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:KMCbuilding.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Municipal_Corporation_Building" title="Karachi Municipal Corporation Building">,                   Karachi Municipal Corporation Building,                 </a>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             The first form of government was a conservancy board established in 1846 to control the spread of cholera in the city.,             <sup id="cite_ref-cdgkhistory_78-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-cdgkhistory-78">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 78,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The board became a municipal commission in 1852, and a municipal committee the following year.,             <sup id="cite_ref-cdgkhistory_78-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-cdgkhistory-78">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 78,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The City of Karachi Municipal Act of 1933 transformed the city administration into a municipal corporation with a mayor, a deputy mayor and 57 councillors.,             <sup id="cite_ref-cdgkhistory_78-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-cdgkhistory-78">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 78,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              In 1948, the ,             <a href="/wiki/Federal_Capital_Territory_(Pakistan)" title="Federal Capital Territory (Pakistan)">,               Federal Capital Territory,             </a>,              of Pakistan was created, comprising approximately 2,103 km,             <sup>,               2,             </sup>,              (812 sq mi) of Karachi and surrounding areas, but this was merged into the province of ,             <a href="/wiki/West_Pakistan" title="West Pakistan">,               West Pakistan,             </a>,              in 1961.,             <sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-79">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 79,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              However, the municipal corporation remained in existence and in 1976 became a metropolitan corporation, followed by the creation of zonal municipal committees, which lasted until 1994.,             <sup id="cite_ref-cdgkhistory_78-3" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-cdgkhistory-78">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 78,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Two years later the metropolitan area was divided into five districts, each with a municipal corporation.,             <sup id="cite_ref-cdgkhistory_78-4" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-cdgkhistory-78">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 78,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             In 2001, five districts of Karachi were merged to form the city district of Karachi. It was structured as a three-tier federation, with the two lower tiers composed of 18 ,             <a href="/wiki/Tehsil" title="Tehsil">,               towns,             </a>,              and 178 ,             <a href="/wiki/Union_councils_of_Pakistan" title="Union councils of Pakistan">,               union councils,             </a>,             ,,             <sup id="cite_ref-tiers_80-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-tiers-80">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 80,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              with each tier focussed on elected councils with some common members to provide "vertical linkage" within the federation.,             <sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-81">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 81,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Each union council comprised thirteen members elected from specified electorates: four men and two women elected directly by the general population; two men and two women elected by peasants and workers; one member for minority communities; two members are elected jointly as the union mayor (,             <i>,               nazim,             </i>,             ) and deputy union mayor (,             <i>,               naib nazim,             </i>,             ).,             <sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-82">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 82,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Each town council was comprised all of the deputy union mayors in the town as well as elected representatives for women, peasants and workers, and minorities.,             <sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-83">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 83,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The district council was comprised all of the union mayors in the district as well as elected representatives for women, peasants and workers, and minorities.,             <sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-84">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 84,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Each council was also included up to three council secretaries and a number of other civil servants. ,             <a href="/wiki/Naimatullah_Khan" title="Naimatullah Khan">,               Naimatullah Khan,             </a>,              was the first Nazim of Karachi and ,             <a href="/wiki/Shafiq-Ur-Rehman_Paracha" title="Shafiq-Ur-Rehman Paracha">,               Shafiq-Ur-Rehman Paracha,             </a>,              was the first district co-ordination officer (DCO) of Karachi, Paracha even served as the last Commissioner of Karachi. ,             <a href="/wiki/Syed_Mustafa_Kamal" title="Syed Mustafa Kamal">,               Syed Mustafa Kamal,             </a>,              was elected City Nazim of Karachi to succeed Naimatullah Khan in 2005 elections, and ,             <a href="/wiki/Nasreen_Jalil" title="Nasreen Jalil">,               Nasreen Jalil,             </a>,              was elected as the City Naib Nazim.,           </p>,           <p>,             Again in 2011, City District Government of Karachi has been de-merged into its five original constituent districts namely ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_East_District" title="Karachi East District">,               Karachi East,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_West_District" title="Karachi West District">,               Karachi West,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Central_District" title="Karachi Central District">,               Karachi Central,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_South_District" title="Karachi South District">,               Karachi South,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Malir_District" title="Malir District">,               Malir,             </a>,             . In November 2013, another district, "Korangi" carved out from District East after which the number of districts in Karachi rose to Six. So there are now six administrative districts in Karachi.,             <sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-85">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 85,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-86">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 86,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-87">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 87,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-88">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 88,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-89">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 89,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              City administrator is Muhammad Hussain Syed,             <sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-90">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 90,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and Municipal Commissioner of Karachi is Matanat Ali Khan.,             <sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-91">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 91,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              There are also six ,             <a href="/wiki/Cantonments_(Pakistan)" title="Cantonments (Pakistan)">,               military cantonments,             </a>,              which are administered by the Military.,           </p>,           <table class="toccolours" style="margin:0 auto; backgrond:none;">,             <tbody>,               <tr>,                 <td style="padding-right:1em;">,                   <ol>,                     <li style="list-style: none; display: inline">,                       <p>,                         <b>,                           <a href="/wiki/Karachi_South" title="Karachi South" class="mw-redirect">,                             Karachi South,                           </a>,                         </b>,                       </p>,                     </li>]]

[ChangeDelta, position: 195, lines: [          <table id="mp-upper" style="width: 100%; margin:4px 0 0 0; background:none; border-spacing: 0px;">] to [          <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">,               Demographics,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Karachi" title="Demographics of Karachi">,               Demographics of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <table class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" align="right" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="margin:0 0 1em 1em; clear:right; text-align:right">]]
[ChangeDelta, position: 198, lines: [                <td class="MainPageBG" style="width:55%; border:1px solid #cef2e0; background:#f5fffa; vertical-align:top; color:#000;">,                   <table id="mp-left" style="width:100%; vertical-align:top; background:#f5fffa;">,                     <tbody>,                       <tr>,                         <td style="padding:2px;">,                           <h2 id="mp-tfa-h2" style="margin:3px; background:#cef2e0; font-family:inherit; font-size:120%; font-weight:bold; border:1px solid #a3bfb1; text-align:left; color:#000; padding:0.2em 0.4em;">,                             <span class="mw-headline" id="From_today.27s_featured_article">,                               From today's featured article,                             </span>,                           </h2>,                         </td>,                       </tr>,                       <tr>,                         <td style="color:#000;">,                           <div id="mp-tfa" style="padding:2px 5px">,                             <div style="float: left; margin: 0.5em 0.9em 0.4em 0em;">,                               <a href="/wiki/File:Tom_pryce_watglen_75.jpg" class="image" title="Tom Pryce racing in 1975">,                                 <img alt="Tom Pryce racing in 1975" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tom_pryce_watglen_75.jpg/133px-Tom_pryce_watglen_75.jpg" width="133" height="66" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tom_pryce_watglen_75.jpg/200px-Tom_pryce_watglen_75.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tom_pryce_watglen_75.jpg/266px-Tom_pryce_watglen_75.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1849" data-file-height="924"/>,                               </a>,                             </div>,                             <p>,                               <b>,                                 <a href="/wiki/Tom_Pryce" title="Tom Pryce">,                                   Tom Pryce,                                 </a>,                               </b>,                                (1949–1977) was a Welsh ,                               <a href="/wiki/Racing_driver" title="Racing driver" class="mw-redirect">,                                 racing driver,                               </a>,                               . He is the only Welsh driver to have won a ,                               <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">,                                 Formula One,                               </a>,                                race (the ,                               <a href="/wiki/Race_of_Champions_(Brands_Hatch)" title="Race of Champions (Brands Hatch)">,                                 Brands Hatch Race of Champions,                               </a>,                               , a non-championship race, in 1975) or to have led a Formula One World Championship Grand Prix (two laps of the ,                               <a href="/wiki/1975_British_Grand_Prix" title="1975 British Grand Prix">,                                 1975 British Grand Prix,                               </a>,                               ). Pryce started his career in Formula One with the small ,                               <a href="/wiki/Token_Racing" title="Token Racing">,                                 Token,                               </a>,                                team, making his only start for them at the ,                               <a href="/wiki/1974_Belgian_Grand_Prix" title="1974 Belgian Grand Prix">,                                 1974 Belgian Grand Prix,                               </a>,                               . Shortly after an impressive performance at the ,                               <a href="/wiki/Formula_Three" title="Formula Three">,                                 Formula Three,                               </a>,                                support race for the ,                               <a href="/wiki/1974_Monaco_Grand_Prix" title="1974 Monaco Grand Prix">,                                 1974 Monaco Grand Prix,                               </a>,                               , Pryce joined the ,                               <a href="/wiki/Shadow_Racing_Cars" title="Shadow Racing Cars">,                                 Shadow,                               </a>,                                team and scored his first points in ,                               <a href="/wiki/1974_German_Grand_Prix" title="1974 German Grand Prix">,                                 Germany,                               </a>,                                in only his fourth race. Pryce ,                               <i>,                                 (pictured during the ,                                 <a href="/wiki/1975_United_States_Grand_Prix" title="1975 United States Grand Prix">,                                   1975 United States Grand Prix,                                 </a>,                                 ),                               </i>,                                later claimed two podium finishes: the first in ,                               <a href="/wiki/1975_Austrian_Grand_Prix" title="1975 Austrian Grand Prix">,                                 Austria in 1975,                               </a>,                                and the second in ,                               <a href="/wiki/1976_Brazilian_Grand_Prix" title="1976 Brazilian Grand Prix">,                                 Brazil a year later,                               </a>,                               . Pryce was considered by his team as a great wet weather driver, and was the fastest driver in the wet conditions of the practice session for the ,                               <a href="/wiki/1977_South_African_Grand_Prix" title="1977 South African Grand Prix">,                                 1977 South African Grand Prix,                               </a>,                               , his final race. During the race, he collided at high speed with a safety marshal, Frederik Jansen van Vuuren, and both men were killed. A memorial to Pryce was unveiled in 2009 in his home town of ,                               <a href="/wiki/Ruthin" title="Ruthin">,                                 Ruthin,                               </a>,                               . (,                               <a href="/wiki/Tom_Pryce" title="Tom Pryce">,                                 <b>,                                   Full article...,                                 </b>,                               </a>,                               ),                             </p>,                             <p>,                               Recently featured: ,                               <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Delius" title="Frederick Delius">,                                 Frederick Delius,                               </a>,                                – ,                               <i>,                                 <a href="/wiki/Thopha_saccata" title="Thopha saccata">,                                   Thopha saccata,                                 </a>,                               </i>,                                – ,                               <a href="/wiki/Erschallet,_ihr_Lieder,_erklinget,_ihr_Saiten!_BWV_172" title="Erschallet, ihr Lieder, erklinget, ihr Saiten! BWV 172">,                                 <i>,                                   Erschallet, ihr Lieder, erklinget, ihr Saiten!,                                 </i>,                                  BWV 172,                               </a>,                             </p>,                             <div style="text-align: right;" class="noprint">,                               <b>,           </tr>,             </tbody>,           </table>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:205px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_City.jpg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Karachi_City.jpg/203px-Karachi_City.jpg" width="203" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Karachi_City.jpg/305px-Karachi_City.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Karachi_City.jpg/406px-Karachi_City.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_City.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <a href="/wiki/Gulistan-e-Jauhar" title="Gulistan-e-Jauhar">,                   Gulistan-e-Jauhar,                 </a>,                  Area of Karachi (Aerial view),               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_population.svg" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Karachi_population.svg/220px-Karachi_population.svg.png" width="220" height="204" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Karachi_population.svg/330px-Karachi_population.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Karachi_population.svg/440px-Karachi_population.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="990" data-file-height="920"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_population.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , Trend of population growth (in millions) in Karachi,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi's inhabitants, locally known as Karachiites, are composed of ethno-linguistic groups from all parts of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,             , as well as migrants from ,             <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">,               South Asia,             </a>,             , making the city's population a diverse ,             <a href="/wiki/Melting_pot" title="Melting pot">,               melting pot,             </a>,             . At the end of the 19th century, the population of the city was about 105,000, with a gradual increase over the next few decades, reaching more than 400,000 on the eve of independence. Estimates of the population range from 15 to 18 million,,             <sup id="cite_ref-npr_93-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-npr-93">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 93,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-94">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 94,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              of which an estimated 90% are migrants from different backgrounds. The city's population is estimated to be growing at about 5% per year (mainly as a result of internal rural-urban ,             <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">,               migration,             </a>,             ), including an estimated 45,000 migrant workers coming to the city every month from different parts of Pakistan.,             <sup id="cite_ref-migrants_95-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-migrants-95">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 95,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             The earliest inhabitants of the area that became Karachi were ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_people" title="Sindhi people">,               Sindhi,             </a>,              tribes such as the ,             <a href="/wiki/Jokhio" title="Jokhio" class="mw-redirect">,               Jokhio,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Mallaah" title="Mallaah">,               Mallaah,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Jats_of_Sindh" title="Jats of Sindh">,               Jat,             </a>,              in the east and ,             <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">,               Baloch,             </a>,              in the west and. Before the end of British colonial rule and the subsequent ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">,               independence,             </a>,              of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,              in 1947, the population of the city was majority ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_people" title="Sindhi people">,               Sindhi,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">,               Baloch,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">,               Muslims,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">,               Hindus,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">,               Sikhs,             </a>,             , but the community is still present numbering around 250,000 residents.,             <sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-96">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 96,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The city was, and still is home to a large community of ,             <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_Muslim" title="Gujarati Muslim" class="mw-redirect">,               Gujarati Muslims,             </a>,              who were one of the earliest settlers in the city, and still form the majority in ,             <a href="/wiki/Saddar_Town" title="Saddar Town">,               Saddar Town,             </a>,             . Important ,             <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_Muslim" title="Gujarati Muslim" class="mw-redirect">,               Gujarati Muslim,             </a>,              communities in the city include the ,             <a href="/wiki/Memon_people" title="Memon people">,               Memon,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Chhipa" title="Chhipa">,               Chhipa,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Ghanchi_(Muslim)" title="Ghanchi (Muslim)">,               Ghanchi,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Khoja" title="Khoja">,               Khoja,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Mustaali" title="Mustaali">,               Bohra,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Tai_(caste)" title="Tai (caste)">,               Tai,             </a>,             . Other early settlers included the ,             <a href="/wiki/Marwari_Muslims" title="Marwari Muslims">,               Marwari Muslims,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">,               Parsis,             </a>,              originally from ,             <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">,               Iran,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Marathi_Muslims" title="Marathi Muslims">,               Marathi Muslims,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Konkani_Muslims" title="Konkani Muslims">,               Konkani Muslims,             </a>,              from ,             <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">,               Maharashtra,             </a>,              (settled in Kokan Town), ,             <a href="/wiki/Goan_Catholics" title="Goan Catholics">,               Goan Catholics,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Indians" title="Anglo-Indians" class="mw-redirect">,               Anglo-Indians,             </a>,             . Most non-Muslims left the city to India in the 1950s, after independence, but there are still small communities of ,             <a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">,               Parsis,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Goan_Catholics" title="Goan Catholics">,               Goan Catholics,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Indians" title="Anglo-Indians" class="mw-redirect">,               Anglo-Indians,             </a>,              in the city.,           </p>,           <div class="thumb tright">,             <div class="thumbinner" style="width:205px;">,               <a href="/wiki/File:Mosque_in_DHA,_Karachi.JPG" class="image">,                 <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Mosque_in_DHA%2C_Karachi.JPG/203px-Mosque_in_DHA%2C_Karachi.JPG" width="203" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Mosque_in_DHA%2C_Karachi.JPG/305px-Mosque_in_DHA%2C_Karachi.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Mosque_in_DHA%2C_Karachi.JPG/406px-Mosque_in_DHA%2C_Karachi.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000"/>,               </a>,               <div class="thumbcaption">,                 <div class="magnify">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Mosque_in_DHA,_Karachi.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge">,                     <img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.24wmf7/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt=""/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 , A mosque of ,                 <a href="/wiki/Defence_Housing_Authority,_Karachi" title="Defence Housing Authority, Karachi">,                   Defence Housing Authority,                 </a>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             The ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">,               independence,             </a>,              of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,              in 1947 saw the influx of ,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">,               Muslim,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Muhajir_people" title="Muhajir people">,               Muhajirs,             </a>,              from ,             <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">,               India,             </a>,              fleeing from ,             <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims" title="Persecution of Muslims">,               anti-Muslim,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Pogram" title="Pogram" class="mw-redirect">,               pograms,             </a>,             . The majority of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Urdu_language" title="Urdu language" class="mw-redirect">,               Urdu,             </a>,             -speaking and other non-,             <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_people" title="Punjabi people">,               Punjabi,             </a>,              Muslim refugees that fled from various Indian states settled in Karachi, which is why the culture of the city is a blend of ,             <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">,               South Asia,             </a>,             . Most of the property vacated by non-Muslims, who left Karachi due to the new settlements made by these refugees, were granted to Muslim refugees through claims on behalf of the property they claimed leaving behind in India.,             <sup id="cite_ref-http_97-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-http-97">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 97,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Today, the descendants of these Muslim refugees are known as ,             <a href="/wiki/Muhajir_people" title="Muhajir people">,               Muhajirs,             </a>,              and form a large, powerful group in Karachi. These Muhajirs include Urdu, ,             <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_Muslims" title="Gujarati Muslims">,               Gujarati,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Marathi_Muslims" title="Marathi Muslims">,               Marathi,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Konkani_Muslims" title="Konkani Muslims">,               Konkani,             </a>,             , Rajasthani, and ,             <a href="/wiki/Mappila" title="Mappila">,               Malabari Muslims,             </a>,              from ,             <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">,               India,             </a>,             . There are around 10 million Biharis and Bengali from Bangladesh. The majority of the Gujaratis in Karachi are ethno-linguistically Sindhis; the majority of ,             <a href="/wiki/Rajasthani_Muslims" title="Rajasthani Muslims">,               Rajasthani Muslims,             </a>,              settled in the city much before the ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">,               independence,             </a>,              of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,              in 1947; the ,             <a href="/wiki/Bihari_people" title="Bihari people">,               Bihari,             </a>,              of Bangladesh speak ,             <a href="/wiki/Bhojpuri_language" title="Bhojpuri language">,               Bhojpuri,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslims" title="Bengali Muslims">,               Bengali Muslims,             </a>,              speak ,             <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">,               Bengali,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_people" title="Rohingya people">,               Rohingya,             </a>,              speak the ,             <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_language" title="Rohingya language">,               Rohingya language,             </a>,             . These small ethno-linguistic groups are being ,             <a href="/wiki/Cultural_assimilation" title="Cultural assimilation">,               assimilated,             </a>,              in the Urdu-speaking community.,             <sup id="cite_ref-http_97-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-http-97">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 97,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             After ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">,               independence,             </a>,              of ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,             , a considerable number of ,             <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_people" title="Punjabi people">,               Punjabi,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">,               Muslims,             </a>,              from Pakistani Punjab settle in Karachi.,             <sup id="cite_ref-http_97-2" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-http-97">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 97,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              There is also a sizeable community of ,             <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_Muslims" title="Kashmiri Muslims">,               Kashmiri Muslims,             </a>,              from the ,             <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_Valley" title="Kashmir Valley">,               Kashmir Valley,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Marathi_people" title="Marathi people">,               Marathi,             </a>,              Hindus and ,             <a href="/wiki/Malayali_people" title="Malayali people" class="mw-redirect">,               Malayali,             </a>,              Muslims in Karachi (the ,             <a href="/wiki/Mappila" title="Mappila">,               Mappila,             </a>,             ), originally from ,             <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">,               Kerala,             </a>,              in ,             <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">,               South India,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-98">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 98,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             The ,             <a href="/wiki/Pashtun_people" title="Pashtun people">,               Pashtuns,             </a>,             , originally from ,             <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">,               Khyber Pakhtunkhwa,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">,               Afghanistan,             </a>,             , the ,             <a href="/wiki/Federally_Administered_Tribal_Areas" title="Federally Administered Tribal Areas">,               Federally Administered Tribal Areas,             </a>,              and northern ,             <a href="/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan" title="Balochistan, Pakistan">,               Balochistan,             </a>,             , are now the city's second largest ethnic group after Muhajirs, these ,             <a href="/wiki/Pashtun_people" title="Pashtun people">,               Pashtuns,             </a>,              are settled in Karachi from decades.,             <sup id="cite_ref-pbs_32-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-pbs-32">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 32,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-The_National_33-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-The_National-33">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 33,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The city of Karachi in Pakistan has the largest concentration of urban ,             <a href="/wiki/Pashtun_diaspora" title="Pashtun diaspora">,               Pakhtun population,             </a>,              in the world, including 50,000 registered ,             <a href="/wiki/Afghan_refugees" title="Afghan refugees" class="mw-redirect">,               Afghan refugees,             </a>,              in the city,,             <sup id="cite_ref-tribune.com.pk_99-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-tribune.com.pk-99">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 99,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-thefridaytimes.com_100-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-thefridaytimes.com-100">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 100,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              meaning there are more Pashtuns in Karachi than in any other city in the world.,             <sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-101">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 101,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              As per current demographic ratio ,             <a href="/wiki/Pashtun_people" title="Pashtun people">,               Pashtuns,             </a>,              are about 25% of Karachi's population.,             <sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-102">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 102,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             After the ,             <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1971">,               Indo-Pakistani War of 1971,             </a>,             , thousands of ,             <a href="/wiki/Bihari_people" title="Bihari people">,               Biharis,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Bengali_people" title="Bengali people">,               Bengalis,             </a>,              from ,             <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">,               Bangladesh,             </a>,              arrived in the city, and today Karachi is home to 1 to 2 million ethnic Bengalis from Bangladesh (see ,             <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshis_in_Pakistan" title="Bangladeshis in Pakistan" class="mw-redirect">,               Bangladeshis in Pakistan,             </a>,             ),,             <sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-103">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 103,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-104">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 104,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              many of whom migrated in the 1980s and 1990s. They were followed by ,             <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_people" title="Rohingya people">,               Rohingya,             </a>,              Muslim refugees from western ,             <a href="/wiki/Burma" title="Burma">,               Burma,             </a>,              (for more information, see ,             <a href="/wiki/Burmese_people_in_Pakistan" title="Burmese people in Pakistan">,               Burmese people in Pakistan,             </a>,             ),,             <sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-105">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 105,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Expulsion_of_Asians_from_Uganda" title="Expulsion of Asians from Uganda">,               Asian refugees,             </a>,              from ,             <a href="/wiki/Uganda" title="Uganda">,               Uganda,             </a>,             . One under-privileged sub-ethnic group is the ,             <a href="/wiki/Siddi" title="Siddi">,               Siddis,             </a>,              (,             <a href="/wiki/Black_people" title="Black people">,               Africans,             </a>,              – Sheedi) who are now naturalised Sindhi speakers. They are descended from African slaves.,             <sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-106">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 106,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Many other refugees from ,             <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">,               Iran,             </a>,              (who stayed till the late 1980s) and the Central Asian countries constituting the former Soviet Union have also settled in the city as political or economic migrants. A large numbers of ,             <a href="/wiki/Arab_people" title="Arab people" class="mw-redirect">,               Arabs,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Filipino_people" title="Filipino people" class="mw-redirect">,               Filipinos,             </a>,              and an economic elite of ,             <a href="/wiki/Sinhalese_people" title="Sinhalese people">,               Sinhalese,             </a>,              from Sri Lanka.,             <sup id="cite_ref-conflictedkarachi_107-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-conflictedkarachi-107">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 107,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Expatriates from China have a history going back to the 1940s; today, many of the Chinese are second-generation children of immigrants who came to the city and worked as dentists, chefs and shoemakers.,             <sup id="cite_ref-conflictedkarachi_107-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-conflictedkarachi-107">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 107,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-DawnKarachi_108-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-DawnKarachi-108">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 108,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi is host to many Western expatriates in Pakistan. During the ,             <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">,               World War II,             </a>,             , about 3,000 ,             <a href="/wiki/Polish_people" title="Polish people" class="mw-redirect">,               Polish,             </a>,              refugees from ,             <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">,               Soviet Union,             </a>,              evacuated to Karachi, by the ,             <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">,               British,             </a>,             . Some of these Polish families settled permanently in the city.,             <sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-109">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 109,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,             <sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-110">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 110,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              There are also communities of American,             <sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-111">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 111,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and British expatriates.,           </p>,           <p>,             According to the last official census of the city, which was held in 1998, the linguistic distribution of the city was: ,             <a href="/wiki/Urdu_language" title="Urdu language" class="mw-redirect">,               Urdu,             </a>,             : 48.52%; ,             <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">,               Punjabi,             </a>,             : 13.94%; ,             <a href="/wiki/Pashto_language" title="Pashto language">,               Pashto,             </a>,             : 11.42%; ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">,               Sindhi,             </a>,             : 7.22%; ,             <a href="/wiki/Balochi_language" title="Balochi language">,               Balochi,             </a>,             : 4.34%; ,             <a href="/wiki/Saraiki_language" title="Saraiki language" class="mw-redirect">,               Saraiki,             </a>,             : 2.11%; others: 12.44%. The others include ,             <a href="/wiki/Dari_(Eastern_Persian)" title="Dari (Eastern Persian)" class="mw-redirect">,               Dari,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">,               Gujarati,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Dawoodi_Bohra" title="Dawoodi Bohra">,               Dawoodi Bohra,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Memon_language" title="Memon language" class="mw-redirect">,               Memon,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Marwari_language" title="Marwari language">,               Marwari,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Brahui_language" title="Brahui language">,               Brahui,             </a>,             , Makrani, ,             <a href="/wiki/Khowar_language" title="Khowar language">,               Khowar,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Burushaski_language" title="Burushaski language" class="mw-redirect">,               Burushaski,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">,               Arabic,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">,               Farsi,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">,               Bengali,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-demographics_112-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-demographics-112">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 112,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             According to the census of 1998, the religious breakdown of the city was: ,             <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">,               Muslim,             </a>,              (96.45%); ,             <a href="/wiki/Christian" title="Christian">,               Christian,             </a>,              (2.42%); ,             <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">,               Hindu,             </a>,              (0.86%); ,             <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">,               Ahmadiyya,             </a>,              (0.17%); others (0.10%) (,             <a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">,               Parsis,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">,               Sikhs,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD" title="Bahá'í" class="mw-redirect">,               Bahá'ís,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Jew" title="Jew" class="mw-redirect">,               Jews,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist" class="mw-redirect">,               Buddhists,             </a>,             ).,             <sup id="cite_ref-usrkarachi_113-0" class="reference">,               <a       </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main articles: ,             <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Karachi" title="Tourism in Karachi" class="mw-redirect">,               Tourism in Karachi,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_beaches_in_Karachi" title="List of beaches in Karachi">,               List of beaches in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright" style="width: 212px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Mazar_-eQuaid_Karachi.jpeg" class="image">,                     <img alt=""    </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Mazar-e-Quaid" title="Mazar-e-Quaid">,                     Mazar-e-Quaid,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_beach,_2007.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt=""
