  </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   Karachi Beach,                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi is a tourist destination for domestic and international tourists. Some tourist attractions near Karachi city are:,           </p>,           <p>,             <b>,               Beaches:,             </b>,              The beaches of Karachi are the main attraction for tourists. There are many beautiful seasides near city like ,             <a href="/wiki/Seaview,_Clifton_Beach" title="Seaview, Clifton Beach">,               Seaview,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Manora_Island" title="Manora Island" class="mw-redirect">,               Manora Island,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Sandspit_Beach" title="Sandspit Beach">,               Sandspit Beach,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Hawke%27s_Bay_Beach" title="Hawke's Bay Beach">,               Hawke's Bay Beach,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Paradise_Point,_Pakistan" title="Paradise Point, Pakistan">,               Paradise Point,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/French_Beach,_Karachi" title="French Beach, Karachi">,               French Beach,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Cape_Monze" title="Cape Monze">,               Cape Monze,             </a>,             , and Nathiagali Beach,           </p>,           <p>,             <b>,               Museums:,             </b>,              The main museum of Karachi is ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Pakistan" title="National Museum of Pakistan">,               National Museum of Pakistan,             </a>,              others are ,             <a href="/wiki/PAF_Museum,_Karachi" title="PAF Museum, Karachi">,               Pakistan Air Force Museum,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Maritime_Museum" title="Pakistan Maritime Museum">,               Pakistan Maritime Museum,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <p>,             <b>,               Parks:,             </b>,              Some popular parks are ,             <a href="/wiki/Bagh_Ibne_Qasim" title="Bagh Ibne Qasim">,               Bagh Ibne Qasim,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Boat_Basin_Park" title="Boat Basin Park">,               Boat Basin Park,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Mazar-e-Quaid" title="Mazar-e-Quaid">,               Mazar-e-Quaid,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Zoo" title="Karachi Zoo">,               Karachi Zoo,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Hill_Park,_Karachi" title="Hill Park, Karachi">,               Hill Park,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Safari_Park,_Karachi" title="Safari Park, Karachi" class="mw-redirect">,               Safari Park,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Bagh-e-Jinnah,_Karachi" title="Bagh-e-Jinnah, Karachi">,               Bagh-e-Jinnah,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/PAF_Museum,_Karachi" title="PAF Museum, Karachi">,               PAF Museum Park,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Maritime_Museum" title="Pakistan Maritime Museum">,               Maritime Museum Park,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <p>,             <b>,               Historic places and buildings:,             </b>,             <a href="/wiki/Chaukhandi_tombs" title="Chaukhandi tombs">,               Chowkandi graveyard,             </a>,              is the most historic place in Karachi, famous for hundred-year old tombs. Historic buildings in the city were constructed in the ,             <a href="/wiki/British_raj" title="British raj" class="mw-redirect">,               British era,             </a>,              like ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Port_Trust" title="Karachi Port Trust">,               Karachi Port Trust,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindh_High_Court" title="Sindh High Court">,               Sindh High Court,             </a>,             . ,             <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Gymkhana,_Karachi" title="Hindu Gymkhana, Karachi">,               Hindu Gymkhana,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Municipal_Corporation_Building" title="Karachi Municipal Corporation Building">,               KMC Head Office,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Khaliq_Deena_Hall" title="Khaliq Deena Hall">,               Ghulam Husain Khalikdina Hall,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Frere_Hall" title="Frere Hall">,               Frere Hall,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Empress_Market" title="Empress Market">,               Empress Market,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Jehangir_Kothari_Parade" title="Jehangir Kothari Parade">,               Jehangir Kothari Parade,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Cathedral,_Karachi" title="Saint Patrick's Cathedral, Karachi">,               St Patrick's Church,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Mohatta_Palace" title="Mohatta Palace">,               Mohatta Palace,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Cantonment_Railway_Station" title="Karachi Cantonment Railway Station" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Cantonment Railway Station,             </a>,              buildings.,             <sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-115">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 115,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             <b>,               Lake and National Park:,             </b>,             <a href="/wiki/Hub_Dam" title="Hub Dam">,               Hub lake,             </a>,              is 56 kilometres away in north of Karachi. It is an ideal place to birds watching, picnic, swimming and fishing. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Kirthar_National_Park" title="Kirthar National Park">,               Kirthar National Park,             </a>,              is also located near this lake. The park is the home of ,             <a href="/wiki/Striped_hyena" title="Striped hyena">,               Striped hyenas,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Wolves" title="Wolves" class="mw-redirect">,               Wolves,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Ratel" title="Ratel" class="mw-redirect">,               Ratels,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Urial" title="Urial">,               Urials,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Chinkara" title="Chinkara">,               Indian Gazelles,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Wild_goat" title="Wild goat">,               Sind wild goats,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_culture">,               Art and culture,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Karachi" title="Culture of Karachi">,               Culture of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright" style="width: 212px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Mohatta_Palace.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Mohatta_Palace.jpg/200px-Mohatta_Palace.jpg" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Mohatta_Palace.jpg/300px-Mohatta_Palace.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Mohatta_Palace.jpg/400px-Mohatta_Palace.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Mohatta_Palace" title="Mohatta Palace">,                     Mohatta Palace,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Khi_National_Museum.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Khi_National_Museum.jpg/200px-Khi_National_Museum.jpg" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Khi_National_Museum.jpg/300px-Khi_National_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Khi_National_Museum.jpg/400px-Khi_National_Museum.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Pakistan" title="National Museum of Pakistan">,                     National Museum of Pakistan,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachijahangir.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Karachijahangir.jpg/200px-Karachijahangir.jpg" width="200" height="110" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Karachijahangir.jpg/300px-Karachijahangir.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Karachijahangir.jpg/400px-Karachijahangir.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="561"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Jehangir_Kothari_Parade" title="Jehangir Kothari Parade">,                     Jehangir Kothari Parade,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_St._Patricks_Cathedral-2.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Karachi_St._Patricks_Cathedral-2.jpg/200px-Karachi_St._Patricks_Cathedral-2.jpg" width="200" height="157" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Karachi_St._Patricks_Cathedral-2.jpg/300px-Karachi_St._Patricks_Cathedral-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Karachi_St._Patricks_Cathedral-2.jpg/400px-Karachi_St._Patricks_Cathedral-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1355" data-file-height="1066"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Cathedral,_Karachi" title="Saint Patrick's Cathedral, Karachi">,                     Saint Patrick's Cathedral, Karachi,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Adnan_Asim%27s_Karachi_City._3_Talwar_(_Swords_)_Clifton,_Karachi.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Adnan_Asim%27s_Karachi_City._3_Talwar_%28_Swords_%29_Clifton%2C_Karachi.jpg/200px-Adnan_Asim%27s_Karachi_City._3_Talwar_%28_Swords_%29_Clifton%2C_Karachi.jpg" width="200" height="148" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Adnan_Asim%27s_Karachi_City._3_Talwar_%28_Swords_%29_Clifton%2C_Karachi.jpg/300px-Adnan_Asim%27s_Karachi_City._3_Talwar_%28_Swords_%29_Clifton%2C_Karachi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Adnan_Asim%27s_Karachi_City._3_Talwar_%28_Swords_%29_Clifton%2C_Karachi.jpg/400px-Adnan_Asim%27s_Karachi_City._3_Talwar_%28_Swords_%29_Clifton%2C_Karachi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="590"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   3 Talwar (Swords), Clifton, Karachi,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Port_Grand,_Karachi.JPG" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Port_Grand%2C_Karachi.JPG/200px-Port_Grand%2C_Karachi.JPG" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Port_Grand%2C_Karachi.JPG/300px-Port_Grand%2C_Karachi.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Port_Grand%2C_Karachi.JPG/400px-Port_Grand%2C_Karachi.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Port_Grand_Food_and_Entertainment_Complex" title="Port Grand Food and Entertainment Complex">,                     Port Grand Food and Entertainment Complex,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi is home to some of Pakistan's important cultural institutions. The ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Academy_of_Performing_Arts" title="National Academy of Performing Arts">,               National Academy of Performing Arts,             </a>,             ,,             <sup id="cite_ref-napa_116-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-napa-116">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 116,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              located in the newly renovated ,             <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Gymkhana,_Karachi" title="Hindu Gymkhana, Karachi">,               Hindu Gymkhana,             </a>,             , offers a two-year diploma course in performing arts that includes classical music and contemporary theatre. The ,             <a href="/wiki/All_Pakistan_Music_Conference" title="All Pakistan Music Conference">,               All Pakistan Music Conference,             </a>,             , linked to the 45-year-old similar institution in ,             <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">,               Lahore,             </a>,             , has been holding its annual music festival since its inception in 2004.,             <sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-117">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 117,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The National Arts Council (,             <i>,               Koocha-e-Saqafat,             </i>,             ) has musical performances and ,             <a href="/wiki/Mushaira" title="Mushaira">,               mushaira,             </a>,              (poetry recitations). The ,             <a href="/wiki/Kara_Film_Festival" title="Kara Film Festival">,               Kara Film Festival,             </a>,              annually showcases independent Pakistani and international films and documentaries. Karachi is home to theatre, music and dance performance groups, such as ,             <b>,               Thespianz Theater,             </b>,             , a professional youth-based, non-profit performing arts group, which works on theatre and arts activities in Pakistan,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">,               [,               <i>,                 <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">,                   <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2010)">,                     citation needed,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </i>,               ],             </sup>,             . A website serving the Pakistani fashion industry is ,             <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.forma.pk/">,               FORMA.pk,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi has museums that present exhibitions on a regular basis, including the ,             <a href="/wiki/Mohatta_Palace" title="Mohatta Palace">,               Mohatta Palace,             </a>,              and the ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Pakistan" title="National Museum of Pakistan">,               National Museum of Pakistan,             </a>,             . ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Expo_Centre" title="Karachi Expo Centre" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Expo Centre,             </a>,              hosts regional and international exhibitions.,           </p>,           <p>,             The everyday lifestyle of Karachi differs from that of other Pakistani cities and towns. The culture of Karachi is characterised by the blending of South Asian, Middle Eastern, Central Asian and Western influences, as well as its status as a major international business centre. After the independence of Pakistan, Karachi received refugees from all over India, whose influence is now evident in the city's sub-cultures.,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">,               [,               <i>,                 <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">,                   <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2014)">,                     citation needed,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </i>,               ],             </sup>,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">,               Architecture,             </span>,           </h3>,           <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">,             See also: ,             <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Karachi" title="Architecture of Karachi" class="mw-redirect">,               Architecture of Karachi,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_architecture" title="Pakistani architecture">,               Pakistani architecture,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Karachi" title="List of tallest buildings in Karachi">,               List of tallest buildings in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi has a collection of buildings and structures of varied ,             <a href="/wiki/Architectural_style" title="Architectural style">,               architectural styles,             </a>,             . The downtown districts of ,             <a href="/wiki/Saddar" title="Saddar">,               Saddar,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Clifton,_Karachi" title="Clifton, Karachi">,               Clifton,             </a>,              contain early 20th-century architecture, ranging in style from the ,             <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">,               neo-classical,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Port_Trust" title="Karachi Port Trust">,               KPT,             </a>,              building to the ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindh_High_Court" title="Sindh High Court">,               Sindh High Court,             </a>,              Building. During the period of British rule, classical architecture was preferred for monuments of the ,             <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">,               British Raj,             </a>,             .,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">,               [,               <i>,                 <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">,                   <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2009)">,                     citation needed,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </i>,               ],             </sup>,              Karachi acquired its first neo-Gothic or Indo-Gothic buildings when ,             <a href="/wiki/Frere_Hall" title="Frere Hall">,               Frere Hall,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Empress_Market" title="Empress Market">,               Empress Market,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Cathedral,_Karachi" title="Saint Patrick's Cathedral, Karachi">,               St. Patrick's Cathedral,             </a>,              were completed. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Mock_Tudor" title="Mock Tudor" class="mw-redirect">,               Mock Tudor,             </a>,              architectural style was introduced in the ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Gymkhana" title="Karachi Gymkhana">,               Karachi Gymkhana,             </a>,              and the Boat Club. ,             <a href="/wiki/Neo-Renaissance_architecture" title="Neo-Renaissance architecture" class="mw-redirect">,               Neo-Renaissance architecture,             </a>,              was popular in the 19th century and was the language for St. Joseph's Convent (1870) and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Sind_Club" title="Sind Club">,               Sind Club,             </a>,              (1883).,             <sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-118">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 118,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The classical style made a comeback in the late 19th century, as seen in ,             <a href="/wiki/Lady_Dufferin_Hospital" title="Lady Dufferin Hospital">,               Lady Dufferin Hospital,             </a>,              (1898),             <sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-119">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 119,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Cantonment_Railway_Station" title="Karachi Cantonment Railway Station" class="mw-redirect">,               Cantt. Railway Station,             </a>,             . While ,             <a href="/wiki/Italianate" title="Italianate" class="mw-redirect">,               Italianate,             </a>,              buildings remained popular, an eclectic blend termed ,             <a href="/wiki/Indo-Saracenic" title="Indo-Saracenic" class="mw-redirect">,               Indo-Saracenic,             </a>,              or Anglo-Mughal began to emerge in some locations.,           </p>,           <p>,             The local mercantile community began acquiring impressive structures. Zaibunnisa Street in the ,             <a href="/wiki/Saddar" title="Saddar">,               Saddar,             </a>,              area (known as Elphinstone Street in British days) is an example where the mercantile groups adopted the ,             <a href="/wiki/Italianate" title="Italianate" class="mw-redirect">,               Italianate,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Indo-Saracenic" title="Indo-Saracenic" class="mw-redirect">,               Indo-Saracenic,             </a>,              style to demonstrate their familiarity with Western culture and their own. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Gymkhana,_Karachi" title="Hindu Gymkhana, Karachi">,               Hindu Gymkhana,             </a>,              (1925) and ,             <a href="/wiki/Mohatta_Palace" title="Mohatta Palace">,               Mohatta Palace,             </a>,              are examples of Mughal revival buildings.,             <sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-120">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 120,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The Sindh Wildlife Conservation Building, located in Saddar, served as a Freemasonic Lodge until it was taken over by the government. There are talks of it being taken away from this custody and being renovated and the Lodge being preserved with its original woodwork and ornate wooden staircase.,             <sup id="cite_ref-Daily_Times_121-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Daily_Times-121">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 121,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Indus Valley School of Art &amp; Architecture is one of the prime examples of Architectural conservation and restoration where an entire Nusserwanjee building from Kharadar area of Karachi has been relocated to Clifton for adaptive reuse in an art school. The procedure involved the careful removal of each piece of timber and stone, stacked temporarily, loaded on the trucks for transportation to the Clifton site, unloaded and re-arranged according to a given layout, stone by stone, piece by piece, and completed within three months.,             <sup id="cite_ref-Indus_Valley_Website_122-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Indus_Valley_Website-122">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 122,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Architecturally distinctive, even eccentric, buildings have sprung up throughout Karachi. Notable example of contemporary architecture include the ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_State_Oil" title="Pakistan State Oil">,               Pakistan State Oil,             </a>,              Headquarters building. The city has examples of modern ,             <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">,               Islamic architecture,             </a>,             , including the ,             <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan_University" title="Aga Khan University">,               Aga Khan University,             </a>,              hospital, ,             <a href="/wiki/Masjid_e_Tooba" title="Masjid e Tooba">,               Masjid e Tooba,             </a>,             , Faran Mosque, Bait-ul Mukarram Mosque, Quaid's Mausoleum, and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Textile_Institute_of_Pakistan" title="Textile Institute of Pakistan">,               Textile Institute of Pakistan,             </a>,             . One of the unique cultural elements of Karachi is that the residences, which are two- or three-story ,             <a href="/wiki/Townhouse" title="Townhouse">,               townhouses,             </a>,             , are built with the front yard protected by a high brick wall. ,             <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Ismail_Chundrigar_Road" title="Ibrahim Ismail Chundrigar Road">,               Ibrahim Ismail Chundrigar Road,             </a>,              features a range of extremely tall buildings. The most prominent examples include the ,             <a href="/wiki/Habib_Bank_Plaza" title="Habib Bank Plaza">,               Habib Bank Plaza,             </a>,             , PRC Towers and the ,             <a href="/wiki/MCB_Tower" title="MCB Tower">,               MCB Tower,             </a>,              which is the tallest skyscraper in ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">,               Pakistan,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-123">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 123,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             Many High-rise buildings are under construction, such as Centre Point near ,             <a href="/wiki/Korangi_Industrial_Area" title="Korangi Industrial Area">,               Korangi Industrial Area,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/IT_Tower" title="IT Tower">,               IT Tower,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Sofitel" title="Sofitel">,               Sofitel,             </a>,              Tower Karachi and Emerald Tower. The Government of Sindh recently,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">,               [,               <i>,                 <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">,                   <span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (December 2009)">,                     when?,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </i>,               ],             </sup>,              approved the construction of two high-density zones, which will host the new city skyline.,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">,               Cuisine,             </span>,           </h3>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_Karachi" title="Cuisine of Karachi" class="mw-redirect">,               Cuisine of Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">,               Biryani,             </a>,              is arguably the most popular food among Karachiites, with numerous variants (,             <a href="/wiki/Awadhi_cuisine" title="Awadhi cuisine">,               Awadhi,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Mughlai_cuisine" title="Mughlai cuisine">,               Mughlai,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Maharashtrian_cuisine" title="Maharashtrian cuisine">,               Bombay,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_cuisine" title="Sindhi cuisine">,               Sindhi,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Memon_cuisine" title="Memon cuisine" class="mw-redirect">,               Memoni,             </a>,              etc.). Meat curries such as ,             <a href="/wiki/Nihari" title="Nihari">,               nihari,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Haleem" title="Haleem">,               haleem,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Dal" title="Dal">,               dal,             </a>,              (,             <a href="/wiki/Lentils" title="Lentils" class="mw-redirect">,               lentils,             </a>,             ), ,             <a href="/wiki/Barbecue" title="Barbecue">,               barbecue,             </a>,              dishes are also very popular, however cuisines vary from one neighbourhood to another, given the diverse nature of ethnic origins that exist. Karachi has a large number of restaurants from local and Fast food to a wide variety of international cuisines such as (,             <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">,               Italian,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">,               Chinese,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">,               Japanese,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">,               Arab,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Korean_cuisine" title="Korean cuisine">,               Korean,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/South_Indian_cuisine" title="South Indian cuisine">,               South Indian,             </a>,             , etc.). The ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_Grand_Food_and_Entertainment_Complex" title="Port Grand Food and Entertainment Complex">,               Port Grand Food and Entertainment Complex,             </a>,              is the largest food street of Asia.,             <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">,               [,               <i>,                 <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">,                   <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2012)">,                     citation needed,                   </span>,                 </a>,               </i>,               ],             </sup>,             The project is a 13-acre facility. Boat Basin is a famous food market while Do Darya is another new location with lots of famous restaurant outlets. Burns Road in Saddar is one of the oldest food streets of city and is still the most popular place to find traditional Pakistani food. The Cuisine of Karachi includes rice cooked with fish called Sindhi Fish Biryani and a pancake made with rice flour which now only exist in the fishing communities in ,             <a href="/wiki/Baba_Bhit_Island" title="Baba Bhit Island" class="mw-redirect">,               Baba Bhit Island,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion.2C_shopping_and_entertainment">,               Fashion, shopping and entertainment,             </span>,           </h3>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main articles: ,             <a href="/wiki/Shopping_malls_in_Karachi" title="Shopping malls in Karachi" class="mw-redirect">,               Shopping malls in Karachi,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Bazaars_in_Karachi" title="Bazaars in Karachi">,               Bazaars in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <p>,             Almost every day entertainment events are held in Karachi ranging from fashion shows, concerts, and small gigs at local cafes.,           </p>,           <p>,             Karachi hosts cultural and fashion shows. In 2009 a four-day-long fashion show was organised in Karachi's luxury Marriott hotel.,             <sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-124">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 124,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The largest shopping mall in Karachi and in Pakistan is ,             <a href="/wiki/Dolmen_Mall_Clifton" title="Dolmen Mall Clifton">,               Dolmen Mall Clifton,             </a>,              or Dolmen City Mall which is located in Dolmen City of the famous Seaview area of Karachi with 2 floors and 51097 square metres or 550000 square feet of retail, dining and entertainment. There are other glitzy shopping malls in the Clifton, like Park Towers one of the famous shopping outfit of Pakistan other shopping areas are Tariq Road, Hyderi, Saddar and Karsaz areas including The Forum, Dolmen Mall Tariq Road and Hyderi, Atrium Mall and the Millenium Mall. There is a shopping mall under construction at Khayaban-e-Roomi called the Ocean Mall which is at the tallest building in Pakistan, ,             <a href="/wiki/Ocean_Towers" title="Ocean Towers">,               Ocean Towers,             </a>,             . The mall will also feature a 4 screen cineplex. Karachi is not only renown for its shopping malls but there are many areas which have shops like Zamzama Boulevard which is known for its designer stores and many cafes. There are many ,             <a href="/wiki/Bazaar" title="Bazaar">,               bazaars,             </a>,              in Karachi such as ,             <a href="/wiki/Bohri_Bazaar" title="Bohri Bazaar" class="mw-redirect">,               Bohri Bazaar,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Soldier_Bazaar" title="Soldier Bazaar">,               Soldier Bazaar,             </a>,             , and ,             <a href="/wiki/Urdu_Bazaar" title="Urdu Bazaar" class="mw-redirect">,               Urdu Bazaar,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <p>,             Foreign clothes brands and Pakistani fashion labels (such as Amir Adnan, Aijazz, Rizwan Beyg, Deepak Perwani, Shayanne Malik, Maria B, Khaadi, Sputnik Footwear, Stone Age, Lark &amp; Finch, Metro Shoes, English Boot House, Cotton &amp; Cotton, Men's Store and Junaid Jamshed) are present in shopping districts of the city. The newly built activity center ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_Grand_Food_and_Entertainment_Complex" title="Port Grand Food and Entertainment Complex">,               Port Grand Food and Entertainment Complex,             </a>,              is located at ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">,               Port of Karachi,             </a>,              near ,             <a href="/wiki/Native_Jetty_Bridge" title="Native Jetty Bridge">,               Native Jetty Bridge,             </a>,             , Dolmen City next to Clifton Beach.,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">,               Sports,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_sports_venues_in_Karachi" title="List of sports venues in Karachi">,               List of sports venues in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright" style="width: 212px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Sindh_Cricket_team_match_with_Australia_in_1935.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Sindh_Cricket_team_match_with_Australia_in_1935.jpg/200px-Sindh_Cricket_team_match_with_Australia_in_1935.jpg" width="200" height="464" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ef/Sindh_Cricket_team_match_with_Australia_in_1935.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ef/Sindh_Cricket_team_match_with_Australia_in_1935.jpg 2x" data-file-width="256" data-file-height="594"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   Match between Sindh &amp; Australia in Karachi on 22 November 1935 was report by Daily Sydney Morning Herald,                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tleft" style="width: 212px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Nat_Std01.JPG" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Nat_Std01.JPG/200px-Nat_Std01.JPG" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Nat_Std01.JPG/300px-Nat_Std01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Nat_Std01.JPG/400px-Nat_Std01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1306" data-file-height="980"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/National_Stadium,_Karachi" title="National Stadium, Karachi">,                     National Stadium,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_Golf_Club3.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Karachi_Golf_Club3.jpg/200px-Karachi_Golf_Club3.jpg" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Karachi_Golf_Club3.jpg/300px-Karachi_Golf_Club3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Karachi_Golf_Club3.jpg/400px-Karachi_Golf_Club3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Golf_Club" title="Karachi Golf Club">,                     Karachi Golf Club,                   </a>,                   , one of the largest golf clubs in Karachi,                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             When it comes to sports Karachi has a distinction, because some sources cite that it was in 1877 at Karachi in (British) India, where the first attempt was made to form a set of rules of badminton,             <sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-125">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 125,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and likely place is said to Frere Hall.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">,               Cricket,             </a>,              in Pakistan has a history of even before the creation of the country in 1947. The first ever international cricket match in Karachi was held on 22 November 1935 between Sindhi and Australian cricket teams. The match was seen by 5,000 Karachiites.,             <sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-126">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 126,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              It is also the most popular sport in Karachi today, which is played in many small grounds around the city, as well as on city streets at night and on weekends. ,             <a href="/wiki/Gully_cricket" title="Gully cricket" class="mw-redirect">,               Gully cricket,             </a>,              is played in the narrow by-lanes of the city.,           </p>,           <p>,             The ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Stadium,_Karachi" title="National Stadium, Karachi">,               National Stadium,             </a>,              is the city's only world-class cricket stadium, and is the second largest cricket stadium in Pakistan, after the ,             <a href="/wiki/Gaddafi_Stadium" title="Gaddafi Stadium">,               Gaddafi Stadium,             </a>,              in ,             <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">,               Lahore,             </a>,             . The inaugural first-class match at the National Stadium was played between Pakistan and India on 26 February 1955 and since then Pakistani national cricket team has won 20 of the 41 ,             <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">,               Test matches,             </a>,              played at the National Stadium.,             <sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-127">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 127,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The first ,             <a href="/wiki/One_Day_International" title="One Day International">,               One Day International,             </a>,              at the National Stadium was against the West Indies on 21 November 1980, with the match going to the last ball.,           </p>,           <p>,             The national team has been less successful in such limited-overs matches at the ground, including a five-year stint between 1996 and 2001, when they failed to win any matches. The city has been host to a number of domestic cricket teams including Karachi,,             <sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-128">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 128,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi Blues,,             <sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-129">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 129,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Karachi Greens,,             <sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-130">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 130,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and Karachi Whites.,             <sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-131">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 131,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The National Stadium hosted two group matches (Pakistan v. South Africa on 29 February and Pakistan v. England on 3 March), and a quarter-final match (South Africa v. West Indies on 11 March) during the ,             <a href="/wiki/1996_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1996 Cricket World Cup">,               1996 Cricket World Cup,             </a>,             .,             <sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-132">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 132,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <p>,             The city has hosted seven editions of the National Games of Pakistan, most recently in 2007.,             <sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-133">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 133,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Sports like badminton, volleyball, and basketball are popular in schools and colleges. ,             <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">,               Football,             </a>,              is especially popular in ,             <a href="/wiki/Lyari_Town" title="Lyari Town">,               Lyari Town,             </a>,             , which has a large Afro-Balochi community and has always been a football-mad locality in Karachi. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Peoples_Football_Stadium" title="Peoples Football Stadium">,               Peoples Football Stadium,             </a>,              is perhaps the largest football stadium in Pakistan with respect to capacity, easily accommodating around 40,000 people.,           </p>,           <p>,             In 2005, the city hosted the ,             <a href="/wiki/SAFF_Championship" title="SAFF Championship">,               SAFF Championship,             </a>,              at this ground, as well as the ,             <a href="/wiki/Geo_Super_Football_League_2007" title="Geo Super Football League 2007" class="mw-redirect">,               Geo Super Football League 2007,             </a>,             , which attracted capacity crowds during the games. The popularity of golf is also increasing, with clubs in Karachi like Dreamworld Resort, Hotel &amp; Golf Club, ,             <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea_Country_Club" title="Arabian Sea Country Club">,               Arabian Sea Country Club,             </a>,             , DA Country &amp; Golf Club. The city has facilities for ,             <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey" title="Field hockey">,               field hockey,             </a>,              (the ,             <a href="/wiki/Hockey_Club_of_Pakistan" title="Hockey Club of Pakistan">,               Hockey Club of Pakistan,             </a>,             , UBL Hockey Ground), ,             <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">,               boxing,             </a>,              (KPT Sports Complex), ,             <a href="/wiki/Squash_(sport)" title="Squash (sport)">,               squash,             </a>,              (,             <a href="/wiki/Jahangir_Khan" title="Jahangir Khan">,               Jahangir Khan,             </a>,              Squash Complex), and ,             <a href="/wiki/Polo" title="Polo">,               polo,             </a>,             . There are marinas and boating clubs. ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Pakistan_Sports_Complex" title="National Bank of Pakistan Sports Complex">,               National Bank of Pakistan Sports Complex,             </a>,              is ,             <a href="/wiki/First-class_cricket" title="First-class cricket">,               First-class cricket,             </a>,              venue and Multi-purpose sports facility in Karachi,,           </p>,           <dl>,             <dt>,               Professional Karachi teams,             </dt>,           </dl>,           <table      1975,                 </td>,               </tr>,             </tbody>,           </table>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">,               Education,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Karachi" title="Education in Karachi">,               Education in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">,             See also: ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Karachi" title="List of schools in Karachi">,               List of schools in Karachi,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_colleges_in_Karachi" title="List of colleges in Karachi">,               List of colleges in Karachi,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Karachi" title="List of universities in Karachi">,               List of universities in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright" style="width: 212px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Bvs_608.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" data-file-width="608" data-file-height="325"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/B._V._S._Parsi_High_School" title="B. V. S. Parsi High School">,                     Bai Virbaijee Soparivala (B.V.S.) Parsi High School,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Hindu_Gymkhana_Karachi.jpeg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Hindu_Gymkhana_Karachi.jpeg/200px-Hindu_Gymkhana_Karachi.jpeg" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Hindu_Gymkhana_Karachi.jpeg/300px-Hindu_Gymkhana_Karachi.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Hindu_Gymkhana_Karachi.jpeg/400px-Hindu_Gymkhana_Karachi.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="583" data-file-height="436"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/National_Academy_of_Performing_Arts" title="National Academy of Performing Arts">,                     National Academy of Performing Arts,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:FAST-NU_Karachi_Thumb.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fe/FAST-NU_Karachi_Thumb.jpg" width="200" height="150" data-file-width="200" data-file-height="150"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Computer_and_Emerging_Sciences" title="National University of Computer and Emerging Sciences">,                     National University of Computer and Emerging Sciences,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:SSUET.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/SSUET.jpg/200px-SSUET.jpg" width="200" height="148" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/SSUET.jpg/300px-SSUET.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/SSUET.jpg/400px-SSUET.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1250" data-file-height="925"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Sir_Syed_University_of_Engineering_and_Technology" title="Sir Syed University of Engineering and Technology">,                     Sir Syed University of Engineering and Technology,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <p>,             Education in Karachi is divided into five levels: primary (grades one through five); ,             <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">,               middle,             </a>,              (grades six through eight); high (grades nine and ten, leading to the ,             <a href="/wiki/Secondary_School_Certificate" title="Secondary School Certificate">,               Secondary School Certificate,             </a>,             ); ,             <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education" title="Secondary education">,               intermediate,             </a>,              (grades eleven and twelve, leading to a Higher Secondary School Certificate); and university programs leading to ,             <a href="/wiki/Undergraduate_education" title="Undergraduate education">,               graduate,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Graduate_school" title="Graduate school">,               advanced,             </a>,              degrees. Karachi has both public and private educational institutions. Most educational institutions are gender-based, from primary to university level.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Grammar_School" title="Karachi Grammar School">,               Karachi Grammar School,             </a>,              is the oldest school in Pakistan and has educated many Pakistani businessmen and politicians. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Narayan_Jagannath_High_School" title="Narayan Jagannath High School">,               Narayan Jagannath High School,             </a>,              in Karachi, which opened in 1855, was the first government school established in Sindh. Other well-known schools include the PakTurk International schools and colleges (formed by association of Turkey and Pakistan) Hamdard Public School, Education Bay [EBay] school located in Karachi (for higher education) Army Public School (C.O.D.), Karachi Public school, ,             <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_School" title="British Overseas School">,               British Overseas School,             </a>,             , L'ecole for Advanced Studies, ,             <a href="/wiki/Bay_View_Academy" title="Bay View Academy" class="mw-redirect">,               Bay View Academy,             </a>,             , the ,             <a href="/wiki/The_CAS_School,_Karachi" title="The CAS School, Karachi" class="mw-redirect">,               CAS School,             </a>,             , Generation's School, ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_American_School" title="Karachi American School">,               Karachi American School,             </a>,             , Aga Khan Higher Secondary School, the Froebel Education Centre (FEC), The Paradise School and College, Grand Folk's English School, Cordoba School for A Levels (founded in 1902 by RJK), ,             <a href="/wiki/Habib_Public_School" title="Habib Public School">,               Habib Public School,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/AL-Murtaza_School" title="AL-Murtaza School" class="mw-redirect">,               AL-Murtaza School,             </a>,             <a href="/wiki/Mama_Parsi_Girls_Secondary_School" title="Mama Parsi Girls Secondary School">,               Mama Parsi Girls Secondary School,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/B._V._S._Parsi_High_School" title="B. V. S. Parsi High School">,               B. V. S. Parsi High School,             </a>,             , Civilizations Public School, The Oasys School, ,             <a href="/wiki/Avicenna_School" title="Avicenna School">,               Avicenna School,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Lyceum_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Lyceum School (page does not exist)">,               The Lyceum School,             </a>,             , Ladybird Grammar School, ,             <a href="/wiki/The_City_School_(Pakistan)" title="The City School (Pakistan)">,               The City School,             </a>,             , ABC Public School, ,             <a href="/wiki/Beaconhouse_School_System" title="Beaconhouse School System">,               Beaconhouse School System,             </a>,             , The Educators schools, ,             <a href="/wiki/Sultan_Mohamed_Shah_Aga_Khan_School,_Karachi" title="Sultan Mohamed Shah Aga Khan School, Karachi" class="mw-redirect">,               Sultan Mohamed Shah Aga Khan School,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shahwilayat_Public_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shahwilayat Public School (page does not exist)">,               Shahwilayat Public School,             </a>,             , Springfield School, ,             <a href="/wiki/St_Patrick%27s_High_School,_Karachi" title="St Patrick's High School, Karachi">,               St Patrick's High School,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_English_High_School" title="St Paul's English High School">,               St Paul's English High School,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/St_Joseph%27s_Convent_School_(Karachi)" title="St Joseph's Convent School (Karachi)">,               St Joseph's Convent School,             </a>,             , St Jude's High School, ,             <a href="/wiki/St_Michael%27s_Convent_School" title="St Michael's Convent School" class="mw-redirect">,               St Michael's Convent School,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Foundation_Public_School" title="Foundation Public School">,               Foundation Public School,             </a>,             ,Aisha Bawanay Academy, Karachi Gems School, Aga Khan School Kharadar, St Peter's High School, White House Grammar School,             <sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-134">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 134,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              and Chiniot Islamia School, St Jude's High School.,           </p>,           <p>,             At intermediate level or in Secondary Education there are many colleges in Karachi. The major segregation of colleges are based upon the specific field of Higher Education. In Karachi, Colleges can be classified as Science Colleges, Commerce Colleges and Arts Colleges. In the category of Science Colleges "Adamjee Govt. Science College",             <sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-135">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 135,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              is one of the leading and prestigious Intermediate Boys College. The College intakes student at secondary level in two science fields; Pre-Engineering and Pre-Medical. The students of Adamjee Science College successfully secure Top three distinguished positions each year in Pre-Engineering and Pre-Medical annual examinations conducted by local government Board of Intermediate Education Karachi.,           </p>,           <p>,             The ,             <a href="/wiki/University_of_Karachi" title="University of Karachi">,               University of Karachi,             </a>,             , known as KU, is Pakistan's largest university, with a student population of 24,000 and one of the largest faculties in the world. It is located next to the ,             <a href="/wiki/NED_University_of_Engineering_and_Technology" title="NED University of Engineering and Technology">,               NED University of Engineering and Technology,             </a>,             , the country's oldest engineering institute. NED University stands for Nadirshaw Edulji Dinshaw University of Engineering and Technology. The current name was given to this institution after receiving a huge donation of "Rs. 150,000 ",             <sup id="cite_ref-neduet.edu.pk_136-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-neduet.edu.pk-136">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 136,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              from Mr. Nadirshaw Edulji Dinshaw. Before this the name of this institution was "Prince of Wales Engineering College".,             <sup id="cite_ref-neduet.edu.pk_136-1" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-neduet.edu.pk-136">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 136,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              At the moment the University has seven faculties and imparting education in 25 different engineering technologies. NED University is the only university in Karachi which has such a huge infra-structure and fully developed laboratory facilities in all 25 engineering technologies.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Textile_Institute_of_Pakistan" title="Textile Institute of Pakistan">,               Textile Institute of Pakistan,             </a>,              (TIP) is a private university, which was established in 1994 with the co-operation of ,             <a href="/wiki/All_Pakistan_Textile_Mills_Association" title="All Pakistan Textile Mills Association">,               All Pakistan Textile Mills Association,             </a>,              (APTMA).,           </p>,           <p>,             In the private sector, the ,             <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Computer_and_Emerging_Sciences" title="National University of Computer and Emerging Sciences">,               National University of Computer and Emerging Sciences,             </a>,              (NUCES-FAST), one of Pakistan's top universities in computer education, operates two campuses in Karachi. ,             <a href="/wiki/Sir_Syed_University_of_Engineering_and_Technology" title="Sir Syed University of Engineering and Technology">,               Sir Syed University of Engineering and Technology,             </a>,              (SSUET) provides training in biomedical engineering, civil engineering, electronics engineering, telecom engineering and computer engineering. ,             <a href="/wiki/Dawood_College_of_Engineering_and_Technology" title="Dawood College of Engineering and Technology">,               Dawood College of Engineering and Technology,             </a>,             , which opened in 1962, offers degree programmes in electronic engineering, chemical engineering, industrial engineering, materials engineering and architecture. ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Institute_of_Economics_%26_Technology" title="Karachi Institute of Economics &amp; Technology" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Institute of Economics &amp; Technology,             </a>,              (KIET) has two campuses in Karachi.,           </p>,           <p>,             The ,             <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plastics_Technology_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plastics Technology Center (page does not exist)">,               Plastics Technology Center,             </a>,              (PTC), located in Karachi's Korangi Industrial Area, is Pakistan's only educational institution providing training in the field of polymer engineering and plastics testing services.,             <sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-137">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 137,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              The ,             <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Business_Administration,_Karachi" title="Institute of Business Administration, Karachi">,               Institute of Business Administration,             </a>,              (IBA), founded in 1955, is the oldest business school outside of North America. The ,             <a href="/wiki/Shaheed_Zulfiqar_Ali_Bhutto_Institute_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Shaheed Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto Institute of Science and Technology">,               Shaheed Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto Institute of Science and Technology,             </a>,              (SZABIST), founded in 1995 by ,             <a href="/wiki/Benazir_Bhutto" title="Benazir Bhutto">,               Benazir Bhutto,             </a>,             , is located in Karachi, with its other campuses in Islamabad, Larkana and Dubai. ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Navy_Engineering_College" title="Pakistan Navy Engineering College">,               Pakistan Navy Engineering College,             </a>,              (PNEC) is a part of the ,             <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Sciences_and_Technology,_Pakistan" title="National University of Sciences and Technology, Pakistan">,               National University of Sciences and Technology,             </a>,              (NUST), offering engineering programs, including electrical engineering and mechanical engineering.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Marine_Academy" title="Pakistan Marine Academy">,               Pakistan Marine Academy,             </a>,              (PMA), founded in 1962, is the only institution of its kind in the public sector training ,             <a href="/wiki/Merchant_Navy" title="Merchant Navy" class="mw-redirect">,               Merchant Navy,             </a>,              Cadets with a degree in Marine Engineering and in Ship Management. ,             <a href="/wiki/Hamdard_University" title="Hamdard University">,               Hamdard University,             </a>,              is the largest private university in Pakistan with faculties including Eastern Medicine, Medical, Engineering, Pharmacy, and Law. It has got Asia's second largest library called 'BAIT UL HIKMA'. ,             <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_University_for_Women" title="Jinnah University for Women">,               Jinnah University for Women,             </a>,              is the first women university in Pakistan. Karachi is home of the head offices of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Chartered_Accountants_of_Pakistan" title="Institute of Chartered Accountants of Pakistan">,               Institute of Chartered Accountants of Pakistan,             </a>,              (ICAP) (established in 1961) and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Cost_and_Management_Accountants_of_Pakistan" title="Institute of Cost and Management Accountants of Pakistan">,               Institute of Cost and Management Accountants of Pakistan,             </a>,              (ICMAP). Among the many other institutions providing business education are the Greenwich University, ,             <a href="/wiki/Iqra_University" title="Iqra University">,               Iqra University,             </a>,              (IU),,             <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Business_Management" title="Institute of Business Management">,               Institute of Business Management,             </a>,              (IoBM), ,             <a href="/wiki/SZABIST" title="SZABIST" class="mw-redirect">,               SZABIST,             </a>,             , and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Business_and_Technology_(Biztek)" title="Institute of Business and Technology (Biztek)" class="mw-redirect">,               Institute of Business and Technology,             </a>,             . Leading medical schools of Pakistan like the ,             <a href="/wiki/Dow_University_of_Health_Sciences" title="Dow University of Health Sciences">,               Dow University of Health Sciences,             </a>,              and the ,             <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan_University" title="Aga Khan University">,               Aga Khan University,             </a>,              are situated in Karachi. ,             <a href="/wiki/PLANWEL" title="PLANWEL">,               PLANWEL,             </a>,             <sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-138">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 138,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              has a CISCO Network Academy as well as iCBT center for ETS Prometric and Pearsons VUE.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Bahria_University" title="Bahria University">,               Bahria University,             </a>,              has a purpose-built campus in Karachi. ,             <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Ali_Jinnah_University" title="Mohammad Ali Jinnah University">,               Mohammad Ali Jinnah University,             </a>,              (MAJU) is a private university in Pakistan. The main campus is in Karachi; the other campus is in Islamabad. The College of Accounting and Management Sciences (CAMS) also has three branches in the city. Sindh Muslim Govt. Science College located at Saddar Town is the oldest college in Karachi. Hamdard University is an accredited private research university with multiple campuses in Karachi and Islamabad, Pakistan.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Darul_%27Uloom_Karachi" title="Darul 'Uloom Karachi">,               Darul 'Uloom Karachi,             </a>,              are among the Islamic schools in Karachi.,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">,               Transportation,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Karachi" title="Transport in Karachi">,               Transport in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <div class="thumb tright" style="width: 212px;">,             <div class="thumbinner">,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_Transport_Network.png" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Karachi_Transport_Network.png/200px-Karachi_Transport_Network.png" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Karachi_Transport_Network.png/300px-Karachi_Transport_Network.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Karachi_Transport_Network.png/400px-Karachi_Transport_Network.png 2x" data-file-width="2828" data-file-height="2128"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   Karachi Transport Network (click to enlarge),                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px;
