width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi-Terminal-00138.JPG" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Karachi-Terminal-00138.JPG/200px-Karachi-Terminal-00138.JPG" width="200" height="139" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Karachi-Terminal-00138.JPG/300px-Karachi-Terminal-00138.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Karachi-Terminal-00138.JPG/400px-Karachi-Terminal-00138.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="714"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   Front view of ,                   <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_International_Airport" title="Jinnah International Airport">,                     Jinnah International Airport,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Karachi_port_and_harbour_aerial.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/46/Karachi_port_and_harbour_aerial.jpg/200px-Karachi_port_and_harbour_aerial.jpg" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/46/Karachi_port_and_harbour_aerial.jpg/300px-Karachi_port_and_harbour_aerial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/46/Karachi_port_and_harbour_aerial.jpg/400px-Karachi_port_and_harbour_aerial.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="399"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">,                     Port of Karachi,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Mangroves_port_Qasim.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Mangroves_port_Qasim.jpg/200px-Mangroves_port_Qasim.jpg" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Mangroves_port_Qasim.jpg/300px-Mangroves_port_Qasim.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Mangroves_port_Qasim.jpg/400px-Mangroves_port_Qasim.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Port_Qasim" title="Port Qasim">,                     Port Qasim,                   </a>,                 </div>,               </div>,               <div style="margin: 1px; width: 202px">,                 <div class="thumbimage">,                   <a href="/wiki/File:Malir_bridge.jpg" class="image">,                     <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Malir_bridge.jpg/200px-Malir_bridge.jpg" width="200" height="151" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Malir_bridge.jpg/300px-Malir_bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Malir_bridge.jpg/400px-Malir_bridge.jpg 2x" data-file-width="756" data-file-height="569"/>,                   </a>,                 </div>,                 <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">,                   <a href="/wiki/Malir_River_Bridge" title="Malir River Bridge">,                     Malir River Bridge,                   </a>,                   . The largest bridge in Pakistan (5,000 m),                 </div>,               </div>,             </div>,           </div>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Rapid_transits">,               Rapid transits,             </span>,           </h3>,           <ul>,             <li>,               <b>,                 <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">,                   Mass Rapid Transit,                 </a>,               </b>,             </li>,           </ul>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Circular_Railway" title="Karachi Circular Railway">,               Karachi Circular Railway,             </a>,              is operation in the city of Karachi since 1969. Metro train system is planned to be built in Karachi. Its name is ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Metro" title="Karachi Metro" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Metro,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <ul>,             <li>,               <b>,                 <a href="/wiki/Bus_Rapid_Transit" title="Bus Rapid Transit" class="mw-redirect">,                   Bus Rapid Transit,                 </a>,               </b>,             </li>,             <li>,               Karachi: Karachi BRT System is a Six Corridor Mass Transit Project whose studies started in 2008. The corridors include: 1. Surjani Town to Jama Cloth Market (21.1 km) 2. Model Colony to Regal Chowk (24.4 km) 3. Landhi to Luck Star Hotel (20.4 km) 4. Baldia to Shershah via Hub River Road (9.7 km) 5. Hwaksbay to Gulbai via Mauripur (11.8 km) 6. Orangi to Board Office (3.9 km). The plan to construct corridor 3 is in progress will be initiated this year (2013). Two Rail based Mass Transit Corridors are also present in the study. All these studies are prepared by JICA. These include: 1. 22.4 km (14. 1 km elevated) route from New Sabzi Mandi to Tower via M A Jinnah Road 2. 18.5 km Elevated route from Nagan Chowrangi to Korangi via Rashid Minhas Road. The Project of ,               <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Circular_Railway" title="Karachi Circular Railway">,                 Karachi Circular Railway,               </a>,                will also be started this year (2013).,             </li>,             <li>,               Karachi Japan International Co-operation Agency (JICA) has prepared a mass transit network for Karachi with 2030 vision suggesting 2 metro system lines and 6 RBT lines, besides ,               <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Circular_Railway" title="Karachi Circular Railway">,                 Karachi Circular Railway,               </a>,                KCR revitalisation programme. The first Green Line Corridor, will be laid from Surjani to Jamia Cloth Market(21 km). The second Red Line Corridor will cover from Model Colony to Regal Chowk via Safoora Chowrangi (24.4 km). The third Corridor will cover from Dawood Chowrangi to Numaish Chowrangi and Lucky Star via 8000 road Korangi and FTC (22 km).JICA has also prepared feasibility study of two RBTS lines (Green line-Surjani to Jama Cloth market and red line-model colony to Regal Chowk via Safoora Goth, university road) and pre-facility of blue line from Sohrab Goth to tower.,             </li>,             <li>,               Karachi being Economic Engine of growth and over 18 million populated is facing tremendous growth in traffic at 7.2 percent annually, beside its disproportionate yearly growth of buses and other transport sources of 17 percent causing congestion and accidents and increasing in travelling time.This project consists of six Corridors in collaboration with JICA. The Basic Design Theme comes from the ,               <a href="/wiki/Bogota" title="Bogota" class="mw-redirect">,                 Bogota,               </a>,               , Columbia, Transmilenio Model. The work would have started in 2009, but due to budget constraits unavailability of feasibility report the work halted.,             </li>,             <li>,               Karachi: The fresh development was made to start BRTS "yellow line" as a Pilot Project in the city. According to KMC, BRTS will be a 22-km route from Dawood Chowrangi to Numaish Chowrangi and Lucky Star via 8000 road Korangi and FTC under public Private Partnership mode where daily rider-ship is about 0.7 million per day. The proposed RBTS would cater 13,000 passengers per hour per direction.,             </li>,           </ul>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Road">,               Road,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             Due to a growing population traffic problems and pollution are major challenges for Karachi. The level of air pollution in Karachi is significantly higher than ,             <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">,               World Health Organization,             </a>,              standards.,             <sup id="cite_ref-The_state_of_ambient_air_quality_in_Pakistan.E2.80.94a_review_139-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-The_state_of_ambient_air_quality_in_Pakistan.E2.80.94a_review-139">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 139,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              A number of new parks (e.g., ,             <a href="/wiki/Bagh_Ibne_Qasim" title="Bagh Ibne Qasim">,               Bagh Ibne Qasim,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Beach_View_Park" title="Beach View Park" class="mw-redirect">,               Beach View Park,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Jheel_Park" title="Jheel Park">,               Jheel Park,             </a>,             ) have been developed and new trees are being planted in the city to improve the environment and reduce the pollution. The construction of new bridges/flyovers, underpasses and signal-free corridors (e.g., Corridor 1: S.I.T.E. to Shahrae Faisal, Corridor 2: North Karachi to Shahrae Faisal, Corridor 3: Safora Goth to Saddar) has improved the traffic flow in Karachi. The completion of Corridor 4 (from the airport to Metropole Hotel) is expected to substantially reduce the travel time to reach the city centre and airport. Another corridor Corridor 5 (Sohrab Goth to Gurumandir) is on its way to be completed.,           </p>,           <p>,             The city which has been declared the world's largest city by population has no ,             <a href="/wiki/Mass_Transit" title="Mass Transit" class="mw-redirect">,               Mass Transit,             </a>,              System.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Lyari_Expressway" title="Lyari Expressway">,               Lyari Expressway,             </a>,              is a highway under construction along the ,             <a href="/wiki/Lyari_River" title="Lyari River">,               Lyari River,             </a>,              in Karachi, ,             <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">,               Sindh,             </a>,             , Pakistan. ,             <a href="/wiki/Lyari_Expressway" title="Lyari Expressway">,               Lyari Expressway,             </a>,             's North bound section is under construction, While the South bound corridor is now completed and it was inaugurated for traffic.,             <sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-140">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 140,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              This toll highway is designed to relieve congestion in the city of Karachi.,           </p>,           <p>,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Northern_Bypass" title="Karachi Northern Bypass" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Northern Bypass,             </a>,              (M10) begins north of Karachi at the end of ,             <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Mohammad Ali Jinnah" class="mw-redirect">,               Mohammad Ali Jinnah Road,             </a>,             , near the junction of the ,             <a href="/wiki/Super_Highway" title="Super Highway" class="mw-redirect">,               M9,             </a>,             . It then continues north for a few kilometres before turning west, where it forms an interchange with the ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Highways_of_Pakistan" title="National Highways of Pakistan">,               N25,             </a>,             . After this interchange it eventually turns south back towards Karachi and merges onto the KPT Flyover at ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Port" title="Karachi Port" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Port,             </a>,             .,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">,               Rail,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             Karachi is linked by rail to the rest of the country by ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Railways" title="Pakistan Railways">,               Pakistan Railways,             </a>,             . The ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_City_Station" title="Karachi City Station" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi City Station,             </a>,              and ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Cantonment_Railway_Station" title="Karachi Cantonment Railway Station" class="mw-redirect">,               Karachi Cantonment Railway Station,             </a>,              are the city's two major railway stations. The railway system handles freight to and from the Karachi port and provides passenger services to people travelling up country. A project to transform the existing, but non-operational, ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Circular_Railway" title="Karachi Circular Railway">,               Karachi Circular Railway,             </a>,              into a modern mass transit system had been approved by the government but has been delayed to 2013 due to lack of funds. The $1.6 billion project will be financed by the ,             <a href="/wiki/Japan_Bank_for_International_Cooperation" title="Japan Bank for International Cooperation">,               Japan Bank for International Cooperation,             </a>,              and will be completed by 2013.,           </p>,           <p>,             The city has an international rail link, the ,             <a href="/wiki/Thar_Express" title="Thar Express">,               Thar Express,             </a>,             . The train links Karachi Cantonment Station with Bhagat Ki Kothi station in ,             <a href="/wiki/Jodhpur" title="Jodhpur">,               Jodhpur,             </a>,             , India.,             <sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-141">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 141,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Air">,               Air,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             The ,             <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_International_Airport" title="Jinnah International Airport">,               Jinnah International Airport,             </a>,              in Karachi is the largest and busiest airport of Pakistan. It handles 10 million ,             <a href="/wiki/Passenger" title="Passenger">,               passengers,             </a>,              a year. The airport receives the largest number of foreign airlines in the country, a total of 35 airlines and cargo operators fly to Jinnah International predominantly from the Middle East and Southeast Asia. All of Pakistan's airlines use Karachi as their primary ,             <a href="/wiki/Transport_hub" title="Transport hub">,               transport hub,             </a>,              including PIA – ,             <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_International_Airlines" title="Pakistan International Airlines">,               Pakistan International Airlines,             </a>,             <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.piac.aero/">,               [3],             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Airblue" title="Airblue">,               Airblue,             </a>,             , and ,             <a href="/wiki/Shaheen_Air_International" title="Shaheen Air International" class="mw-redirect">,               Shaheen Air International,             </a>,             . The city's old ,             <a href="/wiki/Airport_terminal" title="Airport terminal">,               airport terminals,             </a>,              are now used for ,             <a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">,               Hajj,             </a>,              flights, offices, cargo facilities, and ceremonial visits from ,             <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">,               heads of state,             </a>,             . US Coalition forces used the old terminals for their ,             <a href="/wiki/Military_logistics" title="Military logistics">,               logistic,             </a>,              supply operations as well. The city has two other ,             <a href="/wiki/Airstrip" title="Airstrip" class="mw-redirect">,               airstrips,             </a>,             , used primarily by the armed forces.,           </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Sea">,               Sea,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             The largest shipping ports in Pakistan are the ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">,               Port of Karachi,             </a>,              and the nearby ,             <a href="/wiki/Port_Qasim" title="Port Qasim">,               Port Qasim,             </a>,             . These seaports have modern facilities and not only handle trade for Pakistan, but serve as ports for Afghanistan and the landlocked Central Asian countries. Plans have been announced for new passenger facilities at the Port of Karachi.,             <sup id="cite_ref-projects_142-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-projects-142">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 142,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,              Recently Port Qasim Authority (PQA) has announced that an implementation agreement is being signed for the development of a 'pollution free' Coal, Cement and Clinker Terminal (CCCT) worth $175 million with a handling capacity of up to eight million tons per year at port. This step would save the environment from irreparable damages and the health of the port workforce and nearby populations from serious respiratory diseases which would have been a serious threat if the powdery coal was handled in open/bulk on berths at port.,             <sup id="cite_ref-Environment_143-0" class="reference">,               <a href="#cite_note-Environment-143">,                 <span>,                   [,                 </span>,                 143,                 <span>,                   ],                 </span>,               </a>,             </sup>,           </p>,   </p>,           <h3>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Newspapers">,               Newspapers,             </span>,           </h3>,           <p>,             The bulk of Pakistan's periodical publishing industry is centred in Karachi, including magazines such as ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Spider_(computer_magazine)" title="Spider (computer magazine)">,                 Spider,               </a>,             </i>,             , ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Herald_(Pakistan)" title="Herald (Pakistan)">,                 The Herald,               </a>,             </i>,             , ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/Humsay" title="Humsay">,                 Humsay,               </a>,             </i>,             , ,             <i>,               <a href="/wiki/The_Cricketer_(Pakistan)" title="The Cricketer (Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect">,                 The Cricketer,               </a>,             </i>, Moorad Shipping News,               </a>,             </i>,             , and ,             <i>,               The Internet,             </i>,             .,           </p>,           <p>,             Major advertising companies including Interflow Communications, and Orient McCann Erickson have their head offices in Karachi.,           </p>,           <h2>,             <span class="mw-headline" id="Health_and_medicine">,               Health and medicine,             </span>,           </h2>,           <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">,             Main article: ,             <a href="/wiki/List_of_hospitals_in_Karachi" title="List of hospitals in Karachi">,               List of hospitals in Karachi,             </a>,           </div>,           <p>,             Karachi is a centre of research in biomedicine with at least 30 public hospitals and more than 80 private hospitals, including the ,             <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Institute_of_Heart_Diseases" title="Karachi Institute of Heart Diseases">,               Karachi Institute of Heart Diseases,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Cardiovascular_Diseases" title="National Institute of Cardiovascular Diseases" class="mw-redirect">,               National Institute of Cardiovascular Diseases,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Civil_Hospital" title="Civil Hospital">,               Civil Hospital,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/PNS_Rahat" title="PNS Rahat" class="mw-redirect">,               PNS Rahat,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Abbasi_Shaheed_Hospital" title="Abbasi Shaheed Hospital">,               Abbasi Shaheed Hospital,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan_University_Hospital,_Karachi" title="Aga Khan University Hospital, Karachi">,               Aga Khan University Hospital,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Holy_Family_Hospital,_Karachi" title="Holy Family Hospital, Karachi">,               Holy Family Hospital,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Liaquat_National_Hospital" title="Liaquat National Hospital">,               Liaquat National Hospital,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_Postgraduate_Medical_Centre" title="Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre" class="mw-redirect">,               Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre,             </a>,             , ,             <a href="/wiki/Ziauddin_Hospital" title="Ziauddin Hospital" class="mw-redirect">,               Ziauddin Hospital,             </a>,             , and ,             <a             </a>,                                       , approximately 210 ,                                       <a href="/wiki/Byte" title="Byte">,                                         bytes,
